previewParagraphs: Two sides separated by a single point in the La Liga table meet at Son Moix with more than just mid-table pride at stake. Real Mallorca and Osasuna both know that a narrow victory could reshape their season, while another setback would keep them anchored near the danger zone.

These two clubs know each other well, and their recent clashes have usually been balanced affairs. Across the last 5 meetings in all competitions, Mallorca have managed 1 win, Osasuna have taken 1, and there have been 3 draws. That pattern mirrors how these games tend to feel: tight, physical and often decided by small details rather than long stretches of dominance from either side.

Those 5 matches underline how difficult it is for either team to pull clear. Mallorca have avoided defeat in 4 of those 5 encounters, which quietly suggests a slight psychological edge, particularly when they can lean on structure and defensive discipline. For Osasuna, that run shows they are rarely outclassed by Mallorca, but also that turning parity into victories has been an issue.

Mallorca come into this fixture with a solid base of results over their last 6 matches in all competitions: 3 wins, 1 draw and 2 losses. They have scored an average of 1.33 goals and conceded 1.17, generated 14.83 shots per match with 4.83 on target, and held 51.33% possession. Those numbers describe a side that is competitive in most phases, with enough attacking output to trouble opponents without being particularly prolific.

At Son Moix, that profile sharpens. Across their last 3 home matches in all competitions, Mallorca have 2 wins and 1 draw, scoring 1 goal per game and conceding only 0.33. Their shot volume dips slightly to 12.67 attempts and 3.67 on target, with 47% possession, but the defensive stability is striking. Keeping opponents down to a third of a goal per match over that spell has turned home games into controlled, low-scoring contests.

Osasuna’s recent run tells a tougher story. Over their last 6 matches in all competitions they have 1 win, 1 draw and 4 losses, even though their goal figures are level at 1.33 scored and 1.33 conceded per game. They attempt 12.83 shots per match with an impressive 5.17 on target and average 52.17% possession, so the underlying numbers hint at a team that plays with the ball and creates chances but struggles to convert performances into results.

Osasuna’s most recent "home" data is less relevant for this trip, but it is still notable that in their last 3 at El Sadar they have 1 win, 1 draw and 1 loss, scoring 1.67 and conceding only 0.33 on average. That suggests defensive potential, yet the picture changes sharply once they leave Pamplona.

In the La Liga table, Mallorca sit 16th after 13 games with 3 wins, 3 draws and 7 losses. They have scored 13 goals, exactly 1 per match, and conceded 20, an average of 1.54 per game, for a goal difference of -7. The numbers point to a side that is often in games but pays a price for the occasional lapse at the back.

Osasuna, in 17th place, are just below them with 3 wins, 2 draws and 8 defeats from 13 league matches. Their attack has been more blunt at league level, with 10 goals at 0.77 per match, while they concede 16 at 1.23 per game for a goal difference of -6. They are slightly tighter defensively than Mallorca in league play, but the lack of scoring power has made their margin for error extremely small.

Mallorca’s broader trends show a team that has grown stubborn, particularly at home. In their last 8 matches in all competitions they have a 50% win rate, with 4.25 shots on goal and 49.38% possession on average. Stretching the sample out, they have lost 20 of their last 40 matches in all competitions, and 50% of their last 40 in La Liga, which underlines how often they are pushed back at top level, but the current shorter run is clearly more positive.

Recent home form is even more encouraging for Javier Aguirre’s side: in their last 6 home games in all competitions, they have drawn 50% and remained undefeated in 83%. The same pattern holds in La Liga at Son Moix, where across the last 6 home league matches they have also drawn 50% and stayed unbeaten in 83%. Set against that, they have been winless in 16 of their last 20 league fixtures overall, a reminder that consistency across all venues is still missing.

Osasuna’s long view is more troubling. In all competitions they have lost 8 of their last 16 matches and been winless in 8 of their last 10. Away from home that difficulty intensifies: across their last 15 away games in all competitions they have lost 53%, and they have been winless in 83% of their last 12 away fixtures. In La Liga, they have lost 50% of their last 18 matches and have been winless in 82% of their last 11 league outings. Those are the figures of a side that often competes but rarely gets over the line.

Interestingly, Osasuna’s home-based league stats are strong, with 5 clean sheets in their last 12 home league matches and 18 wins across their last 36 home league games, staying undefeated in 80% of their last 10 at El Sadar. The problem for this match is that all of that solidity is linked to Pamplona rather than to their travels.

previewParagraphs: Parma and Udinese arrive at the Ennio Tardini with very different stories but a similar sense of unease. Parma, back in Serie A and still adjusting, have turned stalemates into a way of life, while Udinese mix sporadic punches in attack with a defence that can suddenly collapse. This looks less like a glamour showcase and more like a hard-nosed test of who manages risk better over 90 minutes.

Recent meetings in Emilia give a fair idea of how finely balanced this fixture can be. In the last 4 home matches for Parma against Udinese, the Gialloblù have taken 1 win, shared the points twice and lost once. Nothing in that run suggests a one-sided matchup; instead, it underlines how often these games get decided by small details rather than long spells of dominance.

Parma’s broader picture in Serie A is that of a team still finding its attacking edge. Carlos Antón Cuesta’s side sit 15th with 2 wins, 5 draws and 5 defeats from 12 league games, scoring only 9 goals at an average of 0.75 per match while conceding 15 at 1.25 per game. The negative goal difference of -6 is not catastrophic, but it shows how often they are on the wrong side of tight margins.

The recent form numbers are even more cautious. Across their last 6 matches in all competitions, Parma have 1 win, 3 draws and 2 losses, with a modest scoring average of 1 goal and 1.33 conceded. They are not being blown away, but they rarely pull away either. Their attacking volume is low: 9.17 total shots per match, only 3.33 of those on target, and an average possession of 36.67%, which suggests a side more comfortable ceding the ball and trying to be compact.

At home that pattern becomes even clearer. In the last 3 matches at the Tardini, Parma are winless with 0 wins, 2 draws and 1 defeat, scoring an average of 1 goal and conceding 1.67. They actually shoot a bit more at home, 10.33 attempts per match, but only 2.67 reach the target, and possession drops slightly to 35.67%. The historical trends reinforce that picture: in all competitions, Parma have drawn 50% of their last 12 games and have been winless in 85% of their last 13. In Serie A specifically, they have been winless in 83% of their last 30 league fixtures and winless in 83% of their last 40 home league matches, drawing 50% of their last 12 home games in the competition. This is a team that keeps games close, often without turning them into victories.

Udinese arrive with a different kind of volatility. They are higher in the table in 10th place, with 4 wins, 3 draws and 5 losses from their 12 Serie A outings. They score a little more than Parma, 12 league goals at 1 per match, but also concede more, 20 at an average of 1.67 per game, leaving them with a goal difference of -8. That defensive record is where doubts creep in.

Across their last 6 matches in all competitions, Udinese have 2 wins, 1 draw and 3 defeats, averaging 1 goal scored and 1.83 conceded. Their attacking output is similar to Parma’s at 9.5 shots per match and 3.17 on target, but they tend to have more of the ball with 44% average possession. Away from home, however, the flaws show: over their last 12 away fixtures in all competitions they have lost 58%, and in their last 15 away matches they have lost by 2 or more goals in 6. In Serie A overall they have lost 55% of their last 20 league matches, and 38% of their last 13 in all competitions have ended in defeats by at least 2 goals. When things go wrong, they often go badly wrong.

The recent history trends at home for Udinese back that up indirectly: although those are home numbers, they underline inconsistency. They have lost 6 of their last 12 home league games and gone winless in 9 of their last 11 at home in Serie A. Put together with the away record, Udinese look like a side that relies on individual quality spurts more than a stable platform.

previewParagraphs: Pressure mounts at PlatinumCars Arena as Norrköping aim to halt a seven-match losing run against an Örgryte IS side that tasted victory just days prior. The stage is set for a contest shaped by recent struggles, form trends and the memory of their last encounter.

Just a week separates these two teams from their last clash, and the scars are still fresh for Norrköping. On November 22nd, Örgryte IS hosted Norrköping and delivered a convincing 3-0 result. That match saw Norrköping dominate the ball with 65% possession and create 73 dangerous attacks, yet the cutting edge belonged to Örgryte. Daniel Paulson opened the scoring early in the 10th minute before Noah Christoffersson added a brace, striking in the 43rd and 66th minutes.

Despite taking 22 total shots to Örgryte's 11, Norrköping only managed 5 on target, well below Örgryte’s 8. The clinical finishing from the home side, paired with a resilient rearguard, left Norrköping frustrated and goalless.

Norrköping approach the final in their worst slump of the campaign. Over their last six matches, Martin Falk’s men have lost all six, averaging just 0.5 goals scored while conceding over two per game. At home, their form only slightly improves: 1 win and 2 defeats in their last three, with goals still at a premium.

Örgryte IS haven’t exactly been in a dominant mood but hold the edge based on recent weeks. Andreas Holmberg’s side have taken one win and two draws from their last six, losing three. Their defensive record is stronger, conceding 1.5 per match, while they have managed 0.83 goals per game. Away from home, their form has steadied, with results showing 8 wins and 80% undefeated in their last 15 on the road.

Over the season, Norrköping have struggled in the Allsvenskan. Fourteenth place in the regular season came on the back of 8 wins, 5 draws and 17 defeats from 30 matches, with a goal difference of minus 17. Their tally of 40 goals for and 57 against underscores difficulties at both ends of the field.
Örgryte have been more consistent, especially when considering the substantial number of victories and away resilience that has seen them undefeated in 80% of their last 15 away fixtures.

For Norrköping, the numbers paint a grim picture. They have lost 12 of their last 20 matches in all competitions and endured 82% winless over their last 11. At home, they have lost half of their last 20. The struggles are amplified by losing by 2 or more goals 10 times in their last 26 and 38% of their last 13 home encounters.

Örgryte's recent 40-match run in all competitions includes 22 wins, and they have remained undefeated in 80% of the last 20. In the league, their form is stable with half of their last 14 matches ending in victories. Additionally, their knack for winning by 2 or more goals in 40% of their last 10 illustrates an ability to hit harder when given momentum.

previewParagraphs: A meeting between Werder Bremen and Köln at the Wohninvest Weserstadion brings together two Bundesliga sides sharing mid-table positions but with sharply contrasting home and away fortunes. Bremen's strong home record pairs with Köln’s recent struggles on the road, setting up a contest focused on streaks and recovery.

Werder Bremen and Köln have played out tight affairs in Bremen in recent years. In their last 7 meetings at the Wohninvest Weserstadion, Werder Bremen haven't lost, claiming 3 wins and seeing 4 matches end in draws. This consistent ability to avoid defeat on home turf against Köln stretches back multiple seasons and forms the backbone of Bremen's confidence heading into this fixture.
Köln's challenge in Bremen is underscored by this lack of victories, with recent results showing they often leave with a single point rather than all three.

Werder Bremen arrive in decent shape, with 3 wins, 2 draws, and just 1 loss from their last 6 matches across all competitions. Offensively, they are averaging 1.17 goals scored per match in this period, while conceding just 1. Their last 3 home matches have all ended in victory, with a strong defensive showing allowing just 0.33 goals against per match, alongside an uptick in possession and chance creation.

Köln, meanwhile, have struggled recently, winning only once and drawing another over their previous 6 matches, while losing 4. Their defensive issues are clear with 2.33 goals conceded per game during this run, although they are scoring a respectable 1.67 per match. Their last 3 away league games underline their travel issues: only 0.67 goals scored per match, with 1.33 conceded, and possession dipping below 45% in this period.

Through 11 league matches, Werder Bremen hold 9th place with 4 wins, 3 draws, and 4 defeats. They have found the net 15 times, averaging just over a goal per game, but their leaky defense has surrendered 20 goals for a negative goal difference.

Köln sit close behind at 10th, also on 4 wins, but with 2 draws and 5 losses. Their tally of 20 goals scored is counterbalanced by 19 conceded, giving them a slight positive goal difference. Both teams have secured 12 points out of a possible 33, but Bremen’s recent home form stands out as an advantage.

Bremen have shown resilience at home, going undefeated in 5 of their last 6 matches in all competitions. Over their past 20 Bundesliga home games, they've kept 8 clean sheets and are undefeated in 80% of their last 10 home matches. When facing Köln at home, Bremen have 3 wins and remain unbeaten in their last 7 encounters. They have also managed to win by 2 or more goals in 2 of their last 5 against Köln at this venue.

Köln have been winless in 80% of their last 10 matches in all competitions, losing 50% of their last 12 outings. While their overall away win rate over the past 20 games is 50%, recent league matches have exposed defensive vulnerabilities.

previewParagraphs: Two sides quietly building European ambitions cross paths at the Stadium of Light, as Sunderland and Bournemouth arrive with almost identical records but very different ways of getting there. With both managers leaning into distinct tactical identities and draws dominating their recent trends, this has the feel of a cagey meeting where small details could swing a lot in the Premier League table.

Sunderland’s return to the Premier League has been built on structure and control, and their numbers after 12 rounds back that up. Régis Le Bris has guided his side to 5 wins, 4 draws and 3 losses, with 14 goals scored and only 11 conceded. That average of 0.92 goals against per match is firmly top-half material and has them sitting 7th, just a single place above Bournemouth, who share the same 5-4-3 record but with a very different profile at both ends of the pitch.

The recent history between these two at the Stadium of Light suggests there is not much to separate them. In the last 2 Premier League meetings here, Sunderland have drawn once and lost once, so they have not beaten Bournemouth at home in either of those games. That small sample mirrors what the broader data says: Bournemouth have often found a way to be awkward visitors, even when their overall away form has dipped.

Sunderland’s current form line is balanced. Across their last 6 matches in all competitions they have 2 wins, 2 draws and 2 defeats, scoring 1.17 goals per game and conceding the same 1.17. The underlying numbers tell a story of a compact side happy to play without the ball; they average just 9 total shots and 2.67 shots on target with 43.5% possession. At home, though, they look a little more assertive. In their last 3 at the Stadium of Light they are unbeaten with 1 win and 2 draws, scoring 1.67 and conceding 1 per match, with shots rising to 10.67 per game and possession nudging up to 45.67%.

Those home figures feed into some striking longer-term trends. Sunderland have been undefeated in 25 of their last 30 home matches in all competitions, a superb base that has carried into this Premier League campaign. More broadly, they have not been beaten in 82% of their last 11 matches in all competitions, even if their current streak is slightly less flattering with 3 straight games without a victory. Draws are a recurring theme, with 50% of their last 8 home matches ending level.

Bournemouth arrive with an equally intriguing data profile. Andoni Iraola’s side sit 8th with 19 goals scored and 20 conceded in 12 league games, an average of 1.58 goals for and 1.67 against. In their last 6 matches in all competitions they mirror Sunderland’s record at 2 wins, 2 draws and 2 defeats, but they have been more open, scoring 1.83 and conceding 2.17 per match. Importantly, they generate far more offensive volume, with 13.5 total shots and 5.83 on target per game, backed by 55% average possession.

The story changes when Bournemouth leave the south coast. They are winless in 10 of their last 12 away matches in all competitions and have lost 50% of their last 8 away games. Defensive collapses have been an issue, as they have been beaten by 2 or more goals in 4 of their last 10 away fixtures. That said, Bournemouth have still managed to stay unbeaten in 8 of their last 10 matches overall and 50% of their last 8 games in all competitions have finished level, underlining how often they find a way to share the points.

Recent travel numbers reinforce those concerns. Over Bournemouth’s last 3 away league matches they have 0 wins, 1 draw and 2 defeats, conceding 3.33 goals per game while scoring 1.33. They still fashion chances, with 9.67 shots and 4.67 on target per match, but the defensive vulnerability on the road stands in stark contrast to Sunderland’s long home run of reliability.

In the last 2 Premier League meetings here, Sunderland have drawn once and lost once, so they have not beaten Bournemouth at home in either of those games. previewParagraphs: Manchester City and Leeds United face each other with very different priorities, but a shared sense of urgency. Pep Guardiola’s side is chasing momentum in the Premier League’s upper reaches, while Daniel Farke’s Leeds are trying to pull themselves away from danger. The contrast in form, style and confidence levels sets up a meeting where control and composure could matter as much as pure quality.

When these sides last met in the Premier League, in May 2023 at the Etihad, the scoreline read 2-1 to Manchester City, but the story of the match was one of near-total control from Guardiola’s team. Ilkay Gündogan struck twice inside the opening half hour, both goals coming from City’s trademark patient build-up around the box and late runs from midfield. Leeds struggled to get out, spent long spells in their own half and relied largely on counters and set pieces to trouble City. Rodrigo’s late goal on 85 minutes gave the visitors a lifeline and forced a nervier finish than City would have liked, yet the pattern had been clear: City dictated territory and tempo, while Leeds were limited to chasing the ball and occasional breaks. That dynamic, with City dominant in possession and Leeds having to be extremely efficient with fewer chances, feels very relevant heading into this new meeting.

Across the current Premier League campaign, Manchester City sit 3rd with 7 wins, 1 draw and 4 losses from 12 matches. They average 2 goals scored and only 0.83 conceded per game, for a +14 goal difference that underlines how often they outclass opponents. Leeds, by contrast, are down in 18th after 12 games, with 3 wins, 2 draws and 7 defeats. Their 11 goals scored work out at 0.92 per match, while conceding 22 at 1.83 per game has left them with a sizeable negative goal difference of -11. The statistical gap between the sides in attack and defence is substantial: City create and convert more, and give up fewer chances; Leeds struggle at both ends.

Manchester City’s last 6 matches in all competitions show 4 wins and 2 losses, with an attacking output of 2.33 goals per game and 1.17 conceded. They are averaging 17.83 shots per match and 7 on target, along with 57.83% possession. At the Etihad, the last 3 home fixtures have brought 2 wins and 1 loss, with City again scoring 2.33 per game, allowing just 1, and keeping their shot volume high at 17 attempts per match. Leeds arrive in a far more fragile state. Over their last 6 matches in all competitions, they have 1 win and 5 defeats, scoring only 0.83 and conceding 2.17 per game. They still see a fair amount of the ball at 53% possession on average, but with just 3.83 shots on target from 13 total attempts, they are not turning possession into genuine threat. Their last 3 away matches have all ended in defeat, with just 0.33 goals scored and 2.67 conceded, underlining how vulnerable they are on the road.

City’s broader trends paint the picture of a side that is usually relentless. In their last 15 matches in all competitions they have won 10, and they have not been defeated in 80% of their last 40 across all tournaments. They have won by 2 or more goals in 9 of their last 15 in all competitions, and at home that dominance often grows: 12 wins from their last 15 at the Etihad in all competitions, with 7 clean sheets and 67% of those victories coming by at least a 2 goal margin. In Premier League terms, City have won 58% of their last 12 league matches and have avoided defeat in 16 of their last 20. At home in the league they have won 14 of their last 20 and have not been beaten in 80% of those games. Leeds’ patterns show the opposite direction. Across their last 12 matches in all competitions they have lost 58% and have been winless in 10 of those 12. They have been beaten by 2 or more goals in 43% of their last 7 games, and away from home they have lost 5 of their last 10 and failed to win in 86% of their last 7 on the road, with 40% of those last 10 away defeats coming by at least 2 goals.

With Mateo Kovacic sidelined by an ankle injury, Guardiola is likely to keep faith with the core that has started the last three matches. The shape should resemble a 4-3-3 that can slide into 4-3-2-1 in possession, with plenty of fluidity between the attacking midfielders and wide forwards.

previewParagraphs: As Dundee welcome St Mirren to the Kilmac Stadium at Dens Park on 29 November 2025, both sides find themselves aiming to reverse challenging trends in the Premiership regular season. With the league campaign now well underway, the points on offer feel extra significant for two teams looking to change their fortunes.

Dundee approach this fixture sitting 11th in the Premiership table with only two wins from 13 matches. Their form has been concerning, especially with five defeats in their last six games and a run that has seen them winless in 11 of their last 13 outings in all competitions. Offensively, Dundee have struggled significantly, averaging only 0.69 goals per game and producing less than three shots on target per match across their last six.

Defensively, things have been little better, conceding an average of 2.5 goals per game in that recent stretch. At home, however, there's a glimmer of positivity. In their last three matches at Dens Park, they've won twice, though even those victories came with a moderate 1.67 goals scored and conceded per match. This slight upturn at home could provide some encouragement for Steven Pressley's squad.

Looking at the history between these two clubs, the recent head-to-head gives Dundee cause for optimism. Dundee have claimed two wins from their last three matches against St Mirren, losing the other. In their last four encounters against St Mirren, they've won twice, and in their previous five home fixtures in this matchup, they've won by a two or more goal margin on two occasions.

The trends, however, remain stark. Dundee have lost 21 of their last 40 matches in all competitions and have suffered defeat by a margin of two or more goals in 38% of their last 13 matches. With four consecutive losses and three of those by at least two goals, the need for improvement is urgent.

Turning to St Mirren, their campaign has also been challenging. They occupy 9th place in the league with two wins, four draws, and six losses from 12 matches. Their struggles are evident in a winless streak that stretches to 12 of their last 15 league matches. In their past six games across all competitions, St Mirren have recorded just one win and one draw, losing the other four while conceding an average of 1.83 goals per match.

St Mirren's away form mirrors their overall inconsistency. While they have recorded an average of over 12 shots per game in their last six, turning chances into goals (just 1.17 scored per game) remains problematic. Their league defensive record is more solid than Dundee's, conceding 1.33 per match, but recent trends show they've lost half of their last 12 league games and have been beaten by a two or more goal margin in 43% of their previous seven.

St Mirren are compelled to make at least one change, with Roland Idowu suspended after a recent red card. Otherwise, manager Stephen Robinson will rely on his usual cohort that has featured most frequently in their standard 3-5-2 system.
Delving into the most probable starting elevens, here’s how the teams should line up:

previewParagraphs: With both sides eager to gain crucial ground in the Eredivisie table, Excelsior and NAC Breda prepare to face off at Van Donge & De Roo Stadion. Just a few months removed from a one-sided contest in Rotterdam, both teams have reasons to believe they can deliver a different narrative this time.

Looking back at their previous encounter on June 2, Excelsior firmly held the reins with a convincing 4-1 victory. That contest was a showcase of Excelsior's attacking intent and ball control. Excelsior registered 19 total shots with 8 on target, commanding 69% possession and mounting 90 dangerous attacks. Troy Parrott netted a hat-trick, including a penalty, and the home side saw their advantage reinforced by a Kemper own-goal before C. Staring pulled one back for NAC Breda.

NAC Breda, by comparison, had limited opportunities, just 7 shots and 3 on target, struggling to match Excelsior's intensity and creativity. The disparity in possession and aggressive forward play left NAC with work to do on both ends of the pitch as they regroup for this rematch.

Excelsior heads into the fixture after a mixed spell, with 2 wins, 2 draws, and 2 losses from their last 6 outings in all competitions. Their attacking figures have been somewhat modest, averaging just 1 goal per match while conceding an average of 1.17. Notably, their shot creation remains decent at 14 per game, with 4.67 on target.

At home, Excelsior's recent results show a single win from their last 3, but they have managed a healthy 5 shots on goal per home contest. Possession numbers at the Van Donge & De Roo Stadion hover around 44.33%. Clean sheets have been a feature in half of their last 12 home matches across all competitions, underlining a certain level of defensive resilience.

From a broader perspective, Excelsior sits 14th in the Eredivisie, having taken 4 wins and 1 draw from 13 matches, with 24 goals conceded and a negative goal difference that could cause concern if not addressed in the coming weeks.

NAC Breda, meanwhile, is looking to snap out of an unfavorable streak. In their last 6, they've managed just 1 win, alongside 2 draws and 3 defeats. Goals per match sit at a slightly healthier 1.33 but are undercut by the 2 they concede on average. In away games, difficulties persist: they have been winless in 18 of their last 20 away matches in all competitions, and 19 losses have been recorded in their last 31 on the road.

Their struggles are further highlighted by a 31-match winless run in the Eredivisie overall, and a concerning tendency to lose away by a margin of two or more goals in 5 of their last 13 trips. Still, their shot numbers on the road remain reasonable at 13 per game, with 4 on target.

Both Ruben den Uil for Excelsior and Carl Hoefkens of NAC Breda will likely stick to their preferred formations as recent lineups have shown stability. For Excelsior, Lennard Hartjes remains sidelined with a cruciate ligament tear and will not take part.

previewParagraphs: Two of Ligue 1’s prominent sides meet at the Stade Louis II as Monaco host league leaders PSG. With both teams boasting plenty of attacking prowess, and PSG looking to consolidate their grip on top spot, the 29 November clash has all the right ingredients for a compelling contest.

The last time these sides faced off was in Paris on 7 February 2025, where PSG produced a commanding 4-1 victory over Monaco. The match saw PSG assert control with 64% possession and tally 16 total shots to Monaco’s 10. Vitinha opened the scoring early before Zakaria briefly leveled for Monaco. Kvaratskhelia put PSG ahead after the break, and Ousmane Dembélé netted a late double to complete the scoring. PSG registered 7 shots on target, highlighting their attacking efficiency, while Monaco managed 3 shots on goal and 36% of the ball. PSG also outnumbered Monaco in dangerous attacks by 77 to 47, underlining their dominance in both territory and opportunity creation.

Monaco’s form has been inconsistent, with 3 wins and 3 defeats in their last 6 matches across all competitions. They scored an average of 1.5 goals and conceded 2 per game in that run. At home, things have been less encouraging, winning only 1 and losing 2 of their last 3, scoring just 0.67 goals per game and allowing 1.67 in return.

PSG, meanwhile, approach this fixture on the back of 4 wins, 1 draw, and 1 loss in their last 6 games. They’ve been impressive going forward, averaging 2 goals per match and conceding just 0.83. Their overall dominance is clear, with an average of 21 total shots and 8 shots on target per match, complemented by a staggering 73% average possession in this period.

Monaco’s campaign so far finds them in 8th with 6 wins, 2 draws, and 5 losses from 13 matches. Their scoring rate is decent at 1.92 goals per match, but defensive frailty remains a concern as they have conceded the same number (25) as they’ve scored, resulting in a goal difference of zero.

PSG sit top with 9 wins, 3 draws, and just one defeat in 13 fixtures. Their attack is potent, netting an average of 2.08 goals per game, and their defense is the league’s meanest, conceding only 11 – an average of 0.85 per game. A goal difference of +16 reflects the level of their control on both ends of the pitch so far.

Monaco’s home form is historically solid, undefeated in 80% of their last 40 home games in Ligue 1 and winning 73% of the last 15. However, they have struggled for consistency recently, going winless in 5 of their last 6 on home soil. Against PSG, Monaco have lost 4 of the last 5 meetings, with three of those by a margin of at least two goals.

PSG are unbeaten in 10 of their past 12 matches in all competitions, and incredibly, they have not tasted defeat in 85% of their last 40 away matches. In the league context, PSG have avoided defeat in 14 of their last 15 matches and have won 39% of their last 18 Ligue 1 games by two goals or more – a testament to their attacking depth.

With Luciano Spalletti’s side difficult to beat and Cagliari stuck in a long winless run, this clash sets up as a test of consistency against resilience.

Juventus go into this match in a controlled rhythm rather than free-flowing form, but the numbers suggest a team that knows how to manage games. Unbeaten in their last 6 matches in all competitions, with 3 wins and 3 draws, they have found a balance between security at the back and measured aggression going forward. Cagliari, by contrast, arrive in Turin searching for answers: Fabio Pisacane’s men are winless in their last 8 matches in all competitions and need a statement performance to avoid sliding closer to trouble.

The recent head to head in Turin is heavily tilted in Juventus’ favour. Across the last 5 home meetings with Cagliari, Juventus have won 4 and drawn 1, and they have also managed to win by 2 or more goals in 4 of their last 6 home clashes with the Sardinian side. That pattern fits a longer trend of Juventus using home advantage to impose their structure, while Cagliari often struggle to sustain pressure or keep the scoreline tight over 90 minutes in this fixture.

Juventus’ last 6 matches in all competitions show 3 wins and 3 draws, with an average of 1.67 goals scored and 1 conceded. They are not blowing opponents away but they are consistently creating: 19.83 total shots per match, 8.5 of them on target, with 55% average possession. At the Allianz Stadium, the control has been even clearer in the last 3 games, with 1 win and 2 draws, 1.33 goals scored, only 0.67 conceded, 21.33 shots per match and a strong 60% share of the ball.

Cagliari’s form paints a more fragile picture. Over their last 6 matches in all competitions they have 0 wins, 3 draws and 3 losses, scoring 1 goal per game but conceding 1.83. They average only 8.5 total shots and 3.17 shots on target, with 45.83% possession. Even in their most recent 3 home matches they have not turned performances into victories, with 0 wins, 2 draws and 1 loss and just 0.67 goals scored per match. The contrast in attacking volume and control compared with Juventus is stark.

In Serie A, Juventus sit 7th after 12 games with 5 wins, 5 draws and only 2 defeats. previewParagraphs: With both Lugano and FC Sion neck and neck in the Super League standings, the Stadio di Cornaredo is set to see a matchup that could tip the balance for either side this round.

Lugano are enjoying a strong run, collecting five wins from their last six matches and remarkably undefeated in five of their last six. Their attack has averaged 1.67 goals per game in this period while maintaining a tight defense, conceding just 0.67 on average. At home, they have turned Cornaredo into a fortress with three consecutive victories, conceding just once across those matches.

FC Sion, on the other hand, have experienced a more mixed bag of results. In the past six matches they've registered two wins, two draws, and two losses, scoring and conceding at a rate of 1.5 per match. Delving deeper, their recent away games reveal resilience, with nine undefeated in their last 11 and four clean sheets in the last 10 - a testament to their defensive structure on the road.

The direct encounters between these teams in their last three meetings show Sion holding the upper hand with two wins to Lugano's single success, indicating this clash is often tightly contested and rarely produces a runaway result.

Positioned fifth, Lugano have amassed seven wins, a draw, and five losses from 13 league matches. Their goal output averages 1.38 while conceding 1.31, giving them a narrow positive goal difference. FC Sion, just one place behind in sixth, have played one game more, winning five, drawing five, and losing four, with a slightly stronger offense at 1.57 goals per game, but just a marginally higher concession rate at 1.36. Their overall goal difference stands at +3.

Lugano’s trends highlight their recent strength: winning 58% of their last 12 matches in all competitions, and undefeated in 88% of their last eight. At home, they've won 14 of the last 28 and stayed undefeated in five of their last six.

For Sion, draws have been more prevalent. They’ve split points in 50% of their last eight, and similarly 50% in Super League play. Their away form is noteworthy, with 50% wins and nine undefeated out of the last 11 away games. However, their recent home games have yielded three losses out of six and an 83% winless streak at home - a contrast that speaks to their differing fortunes on the road versus at home.

previewParagraphs: Zürich prepare to face Grasshoppers at Stadion Letzigrund seeking to overturn the outcome of their previous meeting and get their league campaign back on track. The match offers a fresh opportunity for Zürich to avenge a heavy loss just weeks ago and potentially climb the Super League table.

The last encounter between Zürich and Grasshoppers remains fresh in memory, as Grasshoppers triumphed 3-0 at home on October 4, 2025. That evening, Zürich held 59% of the ball and managed 12 attempts, yet it was Grasshoppers who proved clinical. Jonathan Asp Jensen opened the scoring in the 35th minute, Samuel Marques doubled the lead in the 55th, and Nikolas Muci secured victory from the penalty spot in the 82nd minute. Despite Zürich dominating possession and registering 65 dangerous attacks to Grasshoppers' 36, the visitors lacked cutting edge, finding the target with just two shots on goal.

Zürich’s recent fortunes have been mixed. Out of their last six matches across all competitions, they have managed only one victory, drawn once, and suffered four defeats, scoring 1.33 goals and conceding 2 per game on average. At home, their output improves slightly, averaging two goals per match but also conceding 2.33. Their possession numbers at Stadion Letzigrund remain strong at nearly 60%, and they attempt over 19 shots per match in front of familiar surroundings.

Looking at season performance, Zürich sit 8th in the Super League. After 14 matches, they have claimed five wins, two draws, and seven losses, with a negative goal difference of -6 after conceding 27 goals.

Trends suggest inconsistent form: Zürich have lost 50% of their last 24 matches in all competitions. More recently, they have gone winless in 86% of their last 7 matches in the league. On home soil, results have been split, with an even 50% win rate in both their last 12 home matches in all tournaments and in their last 14 league games at Letzigrund.

Grasshoppers’ season tells a challenging story. They are currently 11th, with just three wins, five draws, and six defeats from their 14 matches. The goal difference sits at -9, with 19 goals scored and 28 conceded, translating to an average of 1.36 goals for and 2 against per game.

Recent form for Grasshoppers is concerning. In their last six matches in all competitions, they have won once, drawn twice, and lost three times. Offensively, they have struggled with just 0.83 goals per match, while conceding 2.67. Their away record shows a tendency for difficulty, with 58% of the last 12 away fixtures ending in defeat and six of their most recent league matches winless in 83% of attempts.

Grasshoppers have been particularly unsuccessful on their travels with a run of 12 winless matches in their last 15 away league outings. On the positive side, they have kept four clean sheets in their last ten away league games and have been undefeated in eight of their last ten home league matches.

In the last three head-to-head fixtures, Zürich have claimed two wins against Grasshoppers, but the heavy defeat earlier this season will be a warning sign. With both teams eager to find consistency, the balance could tip quickly depending on who takes their chances.

For team selection, the probable Zürich lineup is expected to be shaped around the ever-present Yanick Brecher in goal and a preferred 4-3-3 formation given their last outings. Key players like Kamberi, Gómez, and Rodić should fill defensive positions, while Zuber and Palacio bring structure to midfield. In attack, Keny and Phaëton will hope to improve the finishing that was missing in the reverse fixture.

previewParagraphs: Two sides separated by just three points in the Premier League table meet with very different stories at home and away. Everton have quietly turned Goodison into a difficult place to visit again, while Newcastle arrive still searching for answers on their travels. The balance of power in this one may hinge on whether David Moyes’ compact structure can blunt Eddie Howe’s forward fluency long enough for the hosts’ new-look attack to make the difference.

Everton’s season has been built on solidity first, and the numbers back that up. Twelve league matches have brought 5 wins, 3 draws and 4 defeats, with 13 goals scored and 13 conceded, an almost perfectly balanced profile at 1.08 scored and 1.08 allowed per game. That foundation has helped Moyes’ side sit 11th, and the recent run hints at a team growing into its shape, especially at home.

The last six matches in all competitions show a pragmatic Everton: 3 wins, 1 draw and 2 losses, while averaging just 1 goal scored and 1.17 conceded. They do not flood opponents with attacks, taking 9.33 shots per match with 3 on target and only 42% possession, which speaks to a side comfortable without the ball, prepared to defend deep and pick their moments.

At Goodison, though, the picture shifts. Across the last three home matches in all competitions, Everton have 2 wins and 1 defeat, scoring 1.33 and conceding 1.33 per game, but crucially increasing their attacking volume to 13.33 shots and 4.67 on target with possession climbing to 51.33%. That trend dovetails with broader long term data. They have been undefeated in 82% of their last 17 home games in all competitions and are undefeated in 10 of their last 12 home matches in the Premier League. Half of their last 10 home league matches have ended in victory, and they have managed 3 wins by 2 or more goals in their last 7 league outings at Goodison, suggesting that when they do get on top, they can turn control into clear scorelines.

Newcastle’s overall trajectory under Eddie Howe still looks positive but is being undermined by travel issues. In all competitions over their last 30 matches they have won 53%, with strong attacking metrics at 5.07 shots on target and 51.3% possession. However, the away numbers tell another story. In their last 12 away games in all competitions they have lost 50% and are winless in 83% of those 12 matches. Clean sheets have come in just 5 of those 12, and while they still average close to 4 shots on target and 52% of the ball, the results have not followed.

In the league, Newcastle sit 14th with 4 wins, 3 draws and 5 defeats, also on 13 goals scored but conceding 15 at 1.25 per game. The recent Premier League stretch is patchy: 3 wins and 3 losses in their last 6, reflecting a side capable of high peaks yet vulnerable when stretched. Their last 6 in all competitions mirror that streak: 3 wins and 3 defeats, scoring 1.5 and conceding 1.5 per match.

The direct recent history slightly favours Newcastle. Over the last 10 meetings, Everton have 3 wins, Newcastle 5, with 2 draws. But Goodison has not been an unhappy hunting ground for the hosts in this fixture. Everton have won 2 of their last 4 home matches against Newcastle and, in their last 5 home clashes, Newcastle have twice lost by 2 or more goals. That points to a pattern where, despite Newcastle’s recent superiority overall, Goodison can tilt the tie back toward the Merseyside club.

previewParagraphs: Kilmarnock and Dundee United prepare for another chapter in their Premiership campaigns, each hoping to turn recent struggles into momentum. With the sides set to clash at Rugby Park, both teams arrive with plenty to prove and vital points at stake.

When Kilmarnock last faced Dundee United in late September, the encounter at Tannadice went the way of the visitors. Kilmarnock earned a 2-0 victory, with Bruce Anderson striking in the 26th minute and Robbie Deas doubling the lead early in the second half. Though the statistical records of shots and possession were not reported, the clinical finishing made all the difference as Kilmarnock punished Dundee United for their defensive lapses.

Since that day, both teams have endured a challenging spell. Kilmarnock’s recent run can only be described as torrid. They have dropped every match in their last six outings, conceding an average of 2.83 goals while finding the net just 0.5 times per game. Rugby Park, typically seen as a stronghold, has offered little respite with three home defeats, only a single goal scored, and an average of over two goals conceded per match.

This pattern extends beyond the last month. Zooming out, Kilmarnock have failed to claim a win in 83% of their last 12 matches across all competitions and are winless in 87% of their last 15 Premiership games. With 6 home losses out of the last 10 and a negative goal difference, the squad urgently needs to steady its form.

Context for the visiting Dundee United reveals a team also searching for consistency. Jim Goodwin’s side sits seventh in the table, three points above Kilmarnock having played a game fewer. Recent results have been a mixed bag: one win, three draws, and two defeats in their last six matches, with an average of 1.17 goals scored and 1.67 conceded. Notably, Dundee United have drawn 50% of their last 10 away fixtures and have gone winless in 82% of their last 11 away matches.

Despite Kilmarnock’s ongoing struggles, Dundee United can’t boast a golden run either. They have gone without a win in 86% of their last seven matches in all competitions and have collected more draws than victories. Contests involving Dundee United tend to be tightly contested, but their inability to turn draws into wins has left them mid-table.

Both teams have been hit by injury absences. Kilmarnock will again be without Matty Kennedy, sidelined by a persistent hip injury, and Djenairo Daniels, out with a knee issue. For the visitors, Isaac Pappoe remains a long-term absentee, and Dario Naamo is unavailable due to eligibility rules.
Given recent lineups and available personnel, here is how the teams are likely to shape up:

previewParagraphs: Both Fortuna Sittard and Heracles approach this Eredivisie clash with plenty at stake. Fortuna’s solid home record faces a Heracles side fresh off a four-game winning streak, setting the stage for an intriguing contest at Fortuna Sittard Stadion.

The upcoming meeting between Fortuna Sittard and Heracles carries significant implications, with both sides seeking to assert themselves in the Eredivisie regular season. Fortuna Sittard’s recent displays at home bring optimism, while Heracles travel to Limburg in confident spirits after enjoying their best spell this season.

The most recent contest at Fortuna Sittard Stadion saw Fortuna edge a 1-0 victory over Heracles on March 8, 2025. Kristoffer Peterson’s penalty in the 66th minute separated the teams in a match shaped by tight margins.

While Heracles managed more dangerous attacks (60 to Fortuna’s 24) and held a slight edge in possession (53%), they struggled to translate that control into meaningful chances. They failed to register a single shot on target, whereas Fortuna hit the target five times from their twelve attempts.
This shows that while Heracles can dictate pace and territory, their inefficiency in front of goal cost them heavily in their previous visit.

Fortuna Sittard have had mixed results lately, with two wins, a draw and three losses in their last six outings. They average 1.17 goals scored and 1.5 conceded per match in this run. At home, their record is healthier — two wins and only one defeat in their last three, conceding just 0.67 goals per match on their own turf.

Heracles, meanwhile, come into this tie with notable momentum. They have picked up four consecutive wins, all in league competition, signaling their strongest form this campaign. Over their last six matches, they’ve posted four wins and two losses, netting three goals per match with an average of 2.67 conceded. On the road, however, they remain vulnerable, having gone winless in 13 of their last 16 away games.

In the league standings, Fortuna Sittard occupy 10th place with 19 goals scored and 21 conceded after 13 matches, while Heracles sit 17th, scoring 21 but shipping 35. Defensive concerns persist for Heracles, and their -14 goal difference speaks volumes compared to Fortuna’s -2.

Fortuna have been formidable at home, avoiding defeat in 8 of their last 10 home matches in all competitions. They have also secured victories in 55% of their last 20 Eredivisie home fixtures and managed clean sheets in 40% across their previous 15 home games.

Heracles have had problems on the road, not winning in 13 out of their last 16 away trips. They have also lost 60% of their previous 30 away matches in all competitions. Nevertheless, their current four-game winning run overall suggests a potential turning point.

Heracles, meanwhile, come into this tie with notable momentum. They have picked up four consecutive wins, all in league competition, signaling their strongest form this campaign. Over their last six matches, they’ve posted four wins and two losses, netting three goals per match with an average of 2.67 conceded. On the road, however, they remain vulnerable, having gone winless in 13 of their last 16 away games.

In the league standings, Fortuna Sittard occupy 10th place with 19 goals scored and 21 conceded after 13 matches, while Heracles sit 17th, scoring 21 but shipping 35. Defensive concerns persist for Heracles, and their -14 goal difference speaks volumes compared to Fortuna’s -2.

Fortuna have been formidable at home, avoiding defeat in 8 of their last 10 home matches in all competitions. They have also secured victories in 55% of their last 20 Eredivisie home fixtures and managed clean sheets in 40% across their previous 15 home games.

Heracles have had problems on the road, not winning in 13 out of their last 16 away trips. They have also lost 60% of their previous 30 away matches in all competitions. Nevertheless, their current four-game winning run overall suggests a potential turning point.
originalTitle: Fortuna Sittard Aim to Harness Home Form Against Heracles’ Resurgence

previewParagraphs: With both Paris FC and Auxerre in need of a morale boost, their clash at Stade Jean Bouin promises a tense and pivotal contest. Paris FC seek a return to form while Auxerre hunt for their first win in weeks, with both sides eager to shift the momentum of their respective campaigns.

It has been a challenging run for Paris FC across all competitions recently, and their last six matches have underlined a need to tighten up at the back. They've come out on top just once in that span, drawn one, and suffered four defeats, scoring an average of 1.33 goals while conceding 2 per outing. At home specifically, recent fortunes have been only marginally better, as they've not managed a single victory in their last three on their own turf.

When narrowing in on matches played at Stade Jean Bouin, Paris FC have produced 14.67 total shots and kept possession for close to 58%. Despite these attacking statistics, results haven't followed, with two losses and a draw in their last three at home. Nonetheless, longer-term numbers paint a more positive picture: they've avoided defeat in 31 of their past 38 at home, highlighting an underlying resilience that's often surfaced on their patch.

Turning to Auxerre, their form has tailed off alarmingly. They haven't posted a win in any of their last eight outings. Stretching further, 13 of their last 15 matches across all competitions have ended without victory. The issues are clear in attack, with only 0.33 goals per match scored on average in their most recent six, while shipping an average of 1.5 goals. Away from home, Auxerre's struggles continue, failing to win in 12 of their last 15 on the road.

The recent head-to-head record between these two sides is quite balanced. In the last five meetings, Paris FC have claimed one victory, with two draws and two losses. However, digging into their recent home meetings with Auxerre, Paris FC have won half of their last six and managed to win by a two-goal margin in two of the last five such encounters. Auxerre have also lost by two or more goals in two of their last three matches against Paris FC, suggesting the hosts have found ways to punish them recently.

On the season as a whole, Paris FC currently occupy 12th in the standings with four wins, two draws, and seven losses after 13 games, averaging 1.54 goals scored and 1.92 conceded per game. Auxerre linger down in 18th, with just two wins, two draws, and nine losses, and a meager seven goals scored to 19 conceded in the league campaign so far.

previewParagraphs: Estádio da Madeira will be the stage as Nacional Madeira face a stern test against an in-form Benfica, who are unbeaten this season. Both teams have plenty at stake at this stage of the Liga Portugal season.

Nacional Madeira come into the game on a three-match winless streak in all competitions, picking up just three wins, two draws, and a single loss over their last six outings. They have struggled slightly at home with one win and two losses in their last three at Estádio da Madeira, averaging just over one goal per match and conceding a little more.

SL Benfica’s recent six games have produced three wins, one draw and two losses with a strong scoring rate of 2.17 goals per match, while conceding only once per outing on average. Over their last three away matches, Benfica managed two wins and a loss, showing efficiency at both ends of the pitch.

Nacional Madeira tend to have less of the ball, averaging just under 48% possession in recent games, while Benfica are more dominant, boasting a near 59% average possession—a key factor that may shape the contest.

The recent head-to-head data paints a daunting picture for Nacional Madeira. The home side have lost all of their last five home matches against Benfica, failing to claim a single point in those encounters. Extending further back, Nacional have lost 90% of their last ten matches in all competitions against Benfica, with nine of those defeats coming by two or more goals.

When you consider Nacional’s winless record in 8 of their last 10 home league matches and Benfica’s remarkable record of being undefeated in 10 of their last 12 away games in all competitions, the challenge facing Tiago Margarido’s side becomes even clearer.

After 11 matches, Nacional Madeira occupy 10th in the Liga Portugal table, with three wins, three draws, and five losses. Their goal difference stands at minus four, having scored 11 and conceded 15. They have not managed to build consistency, reflected in the fact they’ve been winless in 81% of their last 16 league matches.

Benfica sit third, unbeaten in the league with seven wins and four draws. Their attacking might is evident through 23 goals in 11 games—over two per match—while only allowing six against. Crucially, the Eagles have a stellar goal difference of plus 17, underlining their strength at both ends of the pitch.

Nacional Madeira have posted a 53% home win rate across their last 40 matches in all competitions, but that drops to only two home wins in their last 10 league outings. They lost 58% of their last 12 at home and have not managed a run of form in front of their own supporters. In the league, they have also failed to win in 8 of their past 10 at home.

Benfica, meanwhile, demonstrate consistency with wins in 60% of their last 15 away matches and have kept clean sheets in 18 of their last 40 away games. Across all competitions, they have only lost five of their previous 40 matches, evidencing a high level of consistency. Additionally, in league action, they have remained undefeated in 90% of their last 30 matches.

previewParagraphs: Stadio Giuseppe Meazza has seen plenty of open, dramatic duels between Milan and Lazio over the years, but the numbers ahead of this meeting point to something far more controlled and cagey. With Milan pushing hard near the top of Serie A and Lazio building a reputation as one of the most disciplined defensive sides in the league, this looks set to be a tactical contest where small details and individual quality decide the outcome.

Milan come into this clash carrying the rhythm of a side that knows how to manage games. Massimiliano Allegri’s team is on a 12 match undefeated run in all competitions, and has not been beaten in 83% of its last 23 Serie A fixtures. That level of consistency has underpinned their rise to second place, with 7 wins, 4 draws and just 1 defeat from 12 league matches, and a goal difference of +9 built on control rather than chaos.

Recent games between these two sides suggests there is little to separate them on the day. In the last 3 meetings in all competitions, Milan have taken 1 win, Lazio have 1 win, and there has been 1 draw. However, when the venue shifts to San Siro the balance tilts. Milan have won 62% of their last 13 home matches against Lazio, and in 4 of the last 6 home meetings they have won by at least 2 goals, pointing to a pattern where Milan’s structure and wide threats tend to stretch the visitors more than in Rome.

Allegri’s current Milan, though, are not living off historical dominance. Their recent form backs up their league position. Over the last 6 matches in all competitions they have 3 wins and 3 draws, scoring an average of 1.5 goals and conceding 1. At home they look even more assured: in the last 3 games at San Siro they have 2 wins and 1 draw, scoring 1.67 goals per match and conceding 1, while averaging 16.67 total shots and 6.33 shots on target. Those numbers describe a side that regularly creates enough to edge tight contests, even if it rarely runs away with them.

Longer term trends strongly favour Milan in front of their own posts. They have been undefeated in 80% of their last 15 home matches in all competitions and kept clean sheets in 42% of their last 12 at San Siro. In the league, they have won 10 of their last 20 home Serie A games and stayed undefeated in 12 of their last 15. Combine that with a 39% rate of wins by 2 or more goals across their last 23 matches in all competitions, and it is clear why Milan are viewed as one of the most reliable home performers in Italy.

Lazio arrive with a different type of strength. Igor Lasicki’s side sits eighth in Serie A with 5 wins, 3 draws and 4 losses from 12 matches, but the goal data is striking: 15 scored and only 9 conceded, the same defensive record as Milan. Across their last 6 matches in all competitions Lazio have 3 wins, 2 draws and just 1 defeat, yet they have averaged only 0.83 goals scored per match while conceding a tiny 0.33. That defensive resilience is further highlighted by an average of 10.5 shots per game and 4.5 on target, suggesting measured attacking play rather than full throttle football.

On the road, however, there are warning signs for the visitors. Lazio are winless in 86% of their last 7 away matches in all competitions and have lost 3 of their last 6 away games. The defensive base travels well, with clean sheets in 50% of their last 12 away fixtures, but that has not consistently translated into victories. Their last 3 away matches bring 0 wins, 2 draws and 1 loss, with no goals scored and an average of 0.67 conceded. It paints the picture of a side that can frustrate opponents but struggles to convert rare chances into decisive moments away from Rome.

previewParagraphs: Gil Vicente prepare to host CD Tondela at Estádio Cidade de Barcelos on November 29, 2025, sitting near the top of Liga Portugal. Both teams have had contrasting starts, and the record books hint at a clear favourite.

When Gil Vicente and CD Tondela last crossed paths, it was a dominant display from the home side. On May 8, 2022, Gil Vicente produced a comprehensive 3-0 victory that underlined their superiority. K. Fujimoto opened the scoring after halftime in the 56th minute, and S. Lino added two more goals in the 63rd and 77th minutes. That result highlighted Gil Vicente's ability to control the tempo and make their attacks count, while CD Tondela struggled to keep pace or register any reply.

Looking back further, Gil Vicente have taken two wins from their last three home matches against Tondela, and have achieved victory by at least two goals in two of their last five meetings. The home edge and recent head-to-head record clearly sway in Gil Vicente’s favour.

Gil Vicente are enjoying a solid spell, posting three wins and a draw in their last six matches. Their average of 1.67 goals scored per game, coupled with conceding just 0.83, points to balance and efficiency at both ends. At home, they've taken maximum points from their last three matches, keeping a clean sheet each time and averaging over four shots on target.

In contrast, CD Tondela's form leaves little room for optimism. The visitors have one win, one draw, and four losses from their last six outings, letting in 2.17 goals per match on average. Their recent away struggles are evident, as they have lost half of their last ten away matches in all competitions, conceding at a high rate. In fact, Tondela have lost by two or more goals in 43% of their last seven matches overall.

A glance at the league table further illustrates the gulf between these sides. Gil Vicente are fourth, boasting seven wins, two draws, and only two defeats from eleven games. They’ve netted sixteen goals while conceding just five, possessing a healthy goal difference of plus eleven.

CD Tondela, meanwhile, languish in seventeenth place. Out of eleven matches, they’ve managed only one win. A paltry six goals scored and a hefty twenty conceded gives them a negative goal difference of minus fourteen.

Gil Vicente remain undefeated in eight of their last ten matches across all competitions and have won half of their last fourteen fixtures. In the league alone, they haven't been beaten in thirteen of their past sixteen outings, marking them as one of the division's most consistent units. Their home form is particularly strong, with six matches undefeated in their last seven and three clean sheets from their last five matches at Estádio Cidade de Barcelos.

For CD Tondela, the story is reversed. They are without victory in ten of their last twelve league matches, and have gone winless in eighty percent of their past fifteen Liga Portugal games. They have also failed to win in seven out of their last ten away league fixtures, with heavy defeats a common occurrence.

previewParagraphs: The closing stages of the J1 League regular season bring Avispa Fukuoka and Gamba Osaka together at the Best Denki Stadium on November 30, 2025. Both sides come in carrying undefeated streaks and the data points toward a tightly matched contest with only fine margins likely to separate them.

Earlier this year in February, Gamba Osaka edged Avispa Fukuoka 2-1 on home turf in a match that provides plenty of insight for the rematch. Despite the final scoreline, Avispa outshot Gamba 17 to 8, and held 55% of the ball. Their attack generated 84 dangerous moments, but efficiency was the difference, as Shu Kurata capitalized twice on fewer chances while Tomoya Miki's late goal proved insufficient. This meeting showed Fukuoka's capability to control matches, yet underscored Gamba's effectiveness when it mattered.

Looking closely at Avispa Fukuoka's recent form, they have split their last six matches evenly with two wins, two draws, and two losses. The defensive system has held firm, conceding just 0.5 per game over that stretch. Offensively, however, the output has been modest, managing only 0.5 goals per game. When playing at home, things look a touch brighter, with two wins from their last three and a slightly improved attack netting one goal per contest. The home defensive structure remains reliable, giving up only 0.67 goals on average.

Avispa's broader home trends stand out. They have not tasted defeat in 16 of their last 20 home encounters in all competitions, collecting 12 clean sheets from their past 30 at the Best Denki Stadium. The ability to secure draws is also notable: half of their last 8 home games ended level. More recently, a four-match undefeated streak signals resilience down the stretch.

On the other hand, Gamba Osaka's record is impressive across both league and all competitions. The team has taken 10 wins from their last 15, losing just once in their previous six. They are also undefeated in 12 of their most recent 15 matches overall, and five of their last six away from home. Gamba have managed three league wins by two or more goals in their last seven, highlighting the kind of threat they can pose when clicking in attack. The away defensive record is also solid, with eight clean sheets in their latest 20 league journeys.

Recent performances suggest Gamba play with more offensive ambition: they average 1.17 goals per game over the last six, considerably higher than Avispa. Ball retention is another advantage, as seen in their average of 56.5% possession in recent fixtures.

In terms of standings, Gamba hold the edge sitting 8th compared to Avispa's 12th. Gamba's 49 goals in 36 games (1.36 per match) far outstrip Fukuoka's 33 (0.92 per game), but both outfits share a negative goal difference.

Tactical setups should remain familiar. Avispa have consistently rolled out a 3-4-2-1 in recent outings, with lineup consistency in the back three and central midfield. Gamba generally use a 4-2-3-1, occasionally shifting to a 3-4-2-1, but the first formation looks likely this round.
No key players are currently sidelined, ensuring both coaches have their best options available. This should help preserve the usual lineup strengths and add to the match's competitive balance.

previewParagraphs: When Shonan Bellmare meet Shimizu S-Pulse at Lemon Gas Stadium Hiratsuka on 30 November 2025, both teams will be looking to close their regular J1 League campaign on a positive note. With the sides sharing remarkably similar recent numbers and no bragging rights secured in their last face-off, another closely-matched fixture appears on the cards.

The previous meeting between Shonan Bellmare and Shimizu S-Pulse, held on 16 July 2025, ended in a goalless draw. Bellmare might have felt unfortunate not to snatch the win, as they registered 19 shots, 7 on target, and 55% possession. Their 42 dangerous attacks proved persistent, but the breakthrough never materialized.

Meanwhile, Shimizu S-Pulse produced 10 shots, 4 on target, with 45% possession and 33 dangerous attacks. Although their numbers lagged slightly behind, S-Pulse matched Bellmare's tenacity in defense, making for a well-balanced contest throughout.

Shonan Bellmare come into this match with only a single win in their previous six games, along with one draw and four defeats. Their scoring average sits at 1.17 goals per match while conceding 1.33, and their overall recent play reflects modest attacking intent with an average of 11.17 shots per outing.

previewParagraphs: With just one point separating them in the standings and contrasting strengths throughout the season, Kawasaki Frontale and Sanfrecce meet at the Uvance Todoroki Stadium by Fujitsu in what promises to be a tactical and balanced encounter. Both sides bring solid recent form and interesting head to head history into this pivotal J1 League Regular Season fixture on November 30, 2025.

Kawasaki Frontale enters the fixture occupying sixth place, trailing Sanfrecce by just a single point after 36 league matches. The hosts have secured 15 wins, 12 draws, and 9 defeats, scoring an impressive 66 goals while allowing 51 against them. That record balances out to 1.83 goals scored per game and 1.42 goals conceded.

For Sanfrecce, it has been consistency at the back that stands out. They have conceded only 26 goals in 36 matches, the second-best defensive record in the league, and possess a positive goal difference of +16. Their 18 wins, 8 draws, and 10 losses showcase both resilience and the occasional struggle to break down deeper defenses.

The recent home form of Kawasaki Frontale has given them confidence. In their last three home matches against Sanfrecce, Frontale has claimed two victories and drawn the other, staying unbeaten over that run. They have also scored three times per game on average across their last three home outings, while conceding just 1.67 goals per match.

Looking at their overall home performance, Frontale continues an impressive trend: undefeated in 82% of their last 11 home league games. Additionally, they have managed to win exactly half of their last eight home league fixtures and have gone undefeated in 81% of their last 16 home matches within the J1 League.

Recent overall form suggests that Frontale is steady but not overwhelming; in their last six matches, they split results evenly with two wins, two draws, and two defeats. During this sample, they've averaged 1.83 goals scored per match but have allowed 2 goals per contest, which hints at some defensive vulnerabilities.

Sanfrecce, meanwhile, have become a tough opponent both home and away. Their last six matches show three wins, one draw, and two defeats, scoring 1.17 goals and conceding just 0.83 on average. Their away record is robust: over their last 12 away matches in all competitions, they've won 58% and kept clean sheets in 13 of their last 32 away games.

previewParagraphs: As the J1 League regular season nears its conclusion, Kashima Antlers travel to Ajinomoto Stadium to face Tokyo Verdy in a contest between league leaders and a side battling in the lower half of the standings. History and current form set the stage for a compelling matchup with significant implications.

Kashima Antlers come into this fixture on an impressive run, sitting at the top of the table after 36 matches. Their record displays 21 wins, 7 draws, and only 8 losses, with an attacking force notching 55 goals and a remarkably solid defense that has conceded just 30.

Tokyo Verdy, by comparison, have endured a more challenging campaign. With 11 wins, 10 draws, and 15 defeats through the same period, they’ve managed only 22 goals. Their defensive record is somewhat better, having let in 36 goals, but the goal difference remains firmly negative at minus 14. The gap in performance is notable not just in the standings but in nearly every major statistical category.

Recent matches between these two sides have produced a balanced set of outcomes: in the last three meetings Tokyo Verdy and Kashima Antlers each have a win to their name, with one game ending level. This suggests that while Kashima are the dominant side this season, Verdy have shown an ability to compete when these teams meet.

A closer look at Tokyo Verdy’s recent form reveals inconsistency, particularly in attack. Over their last six matches in all competitions, Verdy have logged two wins, two draws, and two losses, but have averaged just 0.33 goals scored and conceded 0.83 per match. Their attacking struggles are underscored by just 3.17 shots on target per match across those games.

At home, however, Verdy have managed to stay tough to beat. Across their last three home encounters, they have won once and drawn twice while not conceding a goal. Their average shots on goal remains low, but defensively they seem well organized at Ajinomoto Stadium.

Kashima Antlers, on the other hand, are riding a 9-match undefeated streak in all competitions. In their last six matches, they have achieved three wins and three draws, averaging a strong 1.67 goals scored and conceding only 0.5 per game. They have consistently dominated on possession, with an average of 53.33% over this stretch, and their attacking efficiency is highlighted by 4.33 shots on target per game.

Looking beyond immediate form, Kashima have stayed unbeaten in 92% of their last 12 matches in all competitions, and 88% of their past eight away games. Clean sheets have become a theme as well, especially away, with the defense blanking opponents in 8 of their last 20 on the road. The long-term consistency in both attack and defense gives them a clear advantage.

With no major injury or suspension concerns for either side, both teams are expected to field their strongest lineups. Based on the last three matches and rotation patterns, probable starting lineups are as follows:

previewParagraphs: When the league leaders PSV Eindhoven meet Volendam at the Philips Stadion, a storyline emerges that features top-tier consistency facing a mid-table side eager to upset the status quo. The matchup promises strong attacking output from the hosts given their recent form and overwhelming track record at home.

The most recent clash between these sides was a comprehensive demonstration of PSV's strength. PSV Eindhoven traveled to Volendam and left with a 5-1 victory, dominating nearly every aspect of the match.

PSV landed 33 shots, 14 of which were on target, and controlled possession for 72% of the game. In contrast, Volendam managed just 8 shots with only 2 reaching the target, and just 28% possession reflected their struggles to threaten the league leaders.

The scoring started in unusual fashion with an own goal by Jordan Teze, but PSV's response was definitive. Ismael Saibari, Jerdy Schouten, Jordan Teze, Ricardo Pepi, and Isaac Babadi all found the net, showcasing PSV's multi-faceted attacking threat.

PSV Eindhoven have remained undefeated in their last 11 matches in all competitions. Over the last 6 matches, they claimed 5 wins and a draw, averaging 3.5 goals scored and only 1.33 conceded per match.

At home, PSV's numbers are even stronger. They have won each of their last 3 home matches, scoring an average of 4.33 goals and enjoying dominance in shot creation with 21.33 attempts per match and holding nearly 60% possession.

Volendam, meanwhile, have been inconsistent in their last six. They have managed 3 wins, 1 draw, and 2 losses, scoring 1.67 and conceding 1.5 goals per match, averaging nearly 10 shots per match and just above 47% possession. Their away matches have been troubling, lacking wins in 88% of their last 8 outings.

PSV top the Eredivisie with 11 wins, 1 draw, and 1 loss across 13 games, scoring 41 goals (over 3 per match) and a healthy goal difference of +24. This balance of attack and defense underlines why they currently lead the standings.

Volendam sit 13th after 13 matches, with 3 wins, 5 draws, and 5 losses. Their goal difference sits at -4, with 17 scored and 21 conceded. The numbers suggest a side that's struggled to find consistency at both ends of the field.

PSV have been a force at home, winning 83% of their last 40 home league matches and staying undefeated in 83% of their last 12 at the Philips Stadion. Furthermore, they have won by two or more goals in half of those home outings, and taken victory in 12 of their last 20.

Volendam’s away form is a concern, with no wins in 88% of their last 8 and a loss in half of their most recent 10 away trips. They've lost by two or more goals in 40% of their last 10 on the road, another pointer to potential difficulties ahead in Eindhoven.

previewParagraphs: Lecce and Torino arrive at the Via del Mare with very different worries but a similar identity: both are hard to break down, both live on narrow margins, and both have been sharing the points a lot more than they would like. With one side edging dangerously close to the relegation places and the other still searching for rhythm in mid‑table, this shapes up less as a spectacle and more as a tactical arm‑wrestle for precious ground in Serie A.

Lecce’s season has slowly drifted towards the danger zone, and this meeting with Torino feels like one of those matches that can nudge a campaign either into deeper trouble or back towards calmer waters. Eusebio Di Francesco’s side sits 17th after 12 games, with only 2 wins, 4 draws and 6 losses, and a goal difference of -8. The numbers tell the story of a group that competes but struggles badly in the final third.

In the league, Lecce average just 0.67 goals per game, scoring 8 and conceding 16. Over their last 6 matches in all competitions they have 1 win, 2 draws and 3 defeats, while scoring 0.5 and conceding 1 goal per match on average. That combination of low scoring and narrow losses fits neatly with their wider trend in Serie A: they have lost 53% of their last 30 league fixtures and have been winless in 32 of their last 40 league games. The margins are always tight, but the points return is thin.

The home numbers add another layer. Lecce are winless in 18 of their last 20 Serie A home matches and have lost 10 of those 20, which underlines why every fixture in Salento now carries real weight. On the positive side, they have kept 3 clean sheets in their last 7 home league games and 4 in their last 10 home matches in all competitions, which suggests the defensive structure is competent. In their last 3 home games in all competitions, they have not scored at all but conceded only 0.33 per match, with 0 wins, 2 draws and 1 loss.

Head to head at the Via del Mare, Lecce have found it difficult against Torino in recent years. In the last 3 home meetings with the Granata they have 1 win and 2 defeats. Even more telling is a broader trend: in their last 7 matches against Torino in all competitions, Lecce have lost by 2 or more goals in 43% of them. That profile hints at a stylistic problem when facing this opponent: when it goes wrong for Lecce in this fixture, it can go wrong quickly.

Torino, coached by Marco Baroni, occupy 12th place with 3 wins, 5 draws and 4 defeats from 12 league games. Curiously, despite sitting higher than Lecce, they have an even worse goal difference of -10, scoring 11 (0.92 per match) and conceding 21 (1.75 per match). Their recent form in all competitions, though, is steadier: over the last 6 games they have 2 wins, 3 draws and just 1 loss, scoring 1 and conceding 1.33 per match. They have been undefeated in 6 of those 7 latest outings, mirroring their Serie A trend where they are undefeated in 86% of their last 7 league matches.

Draws are a recurring theme for Torino. They have drawn 4 of their last 8 matches in all competitions and 50% of their last 8 Serie A games. Away from home the picture is mixed: they have lost 5 of their last 10 away matches in all competitions and are winless in 87% of their last 15 away fixtures. Yet they have also kept clean sheets in 43% of their last 7 away games, suggesting that while victories are scarce, they frequently manage to drag matches into low scoring territory.

From a statistical perspective this encounter leans strongly towards a tight scoreline. Lecce’s home attack has completely dried up in the short term, and their overall chance creation is modest, with 9.67 total shots and 3 shots on target per match over their last 6 games, and an average possession of 46%. Torino, meanwhile, allow the ball, averaging 40.83% possession in that same 6‑match sample but still producing 10.83 shots and 3 on target. The pattern points towards Torino sitting compact, Lecce trying to carry the territorial initiative and both sides relying on set pieces and transitions rather than free‑flowing attacks.
