previewParagraphs: Two teams heading in subtly different directions meet at Selhurst Park, where Crystal Palace’s growing sense of authority under Oliver Glasner is set against a Manchester United side still built around individual brilliance but searching for greater consistency. With Palace riding a strong league run and United leaning on their attack to keep pace, this looks less like a routine trip for a traditional giant and more like a genuine top half battle.

Crystal Palace arrive in this clash with the profile of a quietly efficient top side. Fifth in the Premier League after 12 matches, Glasner’s team have collected 5 wins, 5 draws and only 2 defeats, with a goal difference of +7. The numbers paint a clear picture: they score 1.33 goals per league game and concede just 0.75, a balance that puts them firmly in the conversation for European places rather than just mid-table comfort.

Manchester United, under Ruben Amorim, sit in 10th with 5 wins, 3 draws and 4 losses from the same number of matches. They find the net more often than Palace at 1.58 goals per league game, but also concede at the same 1.58 rate, leaving a neutral goal difference of 0. It underlines the contrast between these sides so far: Palace are built around control and defensive structure, United around a more volatile attacking edge.

The recent history between the two at Selhurst Park leans slightly towards the hosts. In the last three meetings in south London, Palace have 1 win and 2 draws with no defeats. Stretch that view further and Palace have drawn 3 of their last 5 home encounters against United, showing they have largely removed the aura that once surrounded this fixture from a home perspective.

Palace’s broader trends reinforce that impression. In all competitions they have won 50% of their last 26 matches and have been undefeated in 83% of their last 30. At home in all competitions, they have also won 50% of their last 26 and remain particularly solid in league play, where they have stayed unbeaten in 32 of their last 40 Premier League fixtures. At Selhurst in the league, they have not lost in 87% of their last 15 home matches and have kept clean sheets in 42% of their last 12, a foundation that makes them notably difficult to break down.

Recent form backs that up. Across their last 6 matches in all competitions, Palace have 4 wins, 1 draw and just 1 loss, conceding only 0.33 goals per game while scoring 1.67. They are not dominant in possession, averaging 41.33% of the ball, but they use it efficiently. Over those same 6 games they have averaged 11.67 total shots and 4.17 on target. At home, the figures are even stronger: 2 wins and 1 draw from their last 3 matches, with 1.67 goals scored and 0.33 conceded on average, plus a slightly higher shot volume at 13.33 attempts per match.

Manchester United’s recent run is more mixed but still competitive. Over their last 6 matches in all competitions they have 3 wins, 2 draws and 1 defeat, scoring 2 goals per game while conceding 1.33. They typically see more of the ball than Palace, with 50.67% average possession, and generate 14.67 shots per match, 5.67 of them on target. However, there is a note of concern away from home: in their last 20 away matches in all competitions they have been winless in 80% of them, and across their last 10 away fixtures they have lost 5. They have drawn 4 of their last 8 on the road, so stalemates are a recurring theme.

Current streaks fit the same narrative. Palace are undefeated in their last 5 matches in all competitions and generally trend towards resilience, with 42% of their last 12 matches in all competitions being wins by at least 2 goals, suggesting that when they get ahead they are capable of closing matches emphatically. United, by contrast, are winless in their last 3 matches across all competitions, a small but relevant wobble that puts extra pressure on their creative core.
previewText:
Two teams heading in subtly different directions meet at Selhurst Park, where Crystal Palace’s growing sense of authority under Oliver Glasner is set against a Manchester United side still built around individual brilliance but searching for greater consistency. With Palace riding a strong league run and United leaning on their attack to keep pace, this looks less like a routine trip for a traditional giant and more like a genuine top half battle.

Crystal Palace arrive in this clash with the profile of a quietly efficient top side. Fifth in the Premier League after 12 matches, Glasner’s team have collected 5 wins, 5 draws and only 2 defeats, with a goal difference of +7. The numbers paint a clear picture: they score 1.33 goals per league game and concede just 0.75, a balance that puts them firmly in the conversation for European places rather than just mid-table comfort.

Manchester United, under Ruben Amorim, sit in 10th with 5 wins, 3 draws and 4 losses from the same number of matches. They find the net more often than Palace at 1.58 goals per league game, but also concede at the same 1.58 rate, leaving a neutral goal difference of 0. It underlines the contrast between these sides so far: Palace are built around control and defensive structure, United around a more volatile attacking edge.

The recent history between the two at Selhurst Park leans slightly towards the hosts. In the last three meetings in south London, Palace have 1 win and 2 draws with no defeats. Stretch that view further and Palace have drawn 3 of their last 5 home encounters against United, showing they have largely removed the aura that once surrounded this fixture from a home perspective.

Palace’s broader trends reinforce that impression. In all competitions they have won 50% of their last 26 matches and have been undefeated in 83% of their last 30. At home in all competitions, they have also won 50% of their last 26 and remain particularly solid in league play, where they have stayed unbeaten in 32 of their last 40 Premier League fixtures. At Selhurst in the league, they have not lost in 87% of their last 15 home matches and have kept clean sheets in 42% of their last 12, a foundation that makes them notably difficult to break down.

Recent form backs that up. Across their last 6 matches in all competitions, Palace have 4 wins, 1 draw and just 1 loss, conceding only 0.33 goals per game while scoring 1.67. They are not dominant in possession, averaging 41.33% of the ball, but they use it efficiently. Over those same 6 games they have averaged 11.67 total shots and 4.17 on target. At home, the figures are even stronger: 2 wins and 1 draw from their last 3 matches, with 1.67 goals scored and 0.33 conceded on average, plus a slightly higher shot volume at 13.33 attempts per match.

Manchester United’s recent run is more mixed but still competitive. Over their last 6 matches in all competitions they have 3 wins, 2 draws and 1 defeat, scoring 2 goals per game while conceding 1.33. They typically see more of the ball than Palace, with 50.67% average possession, and generate 14.67 shots per match, 5.67 of them on target. However, there is a note of concern away from home: in their last 20 away matches in all competitions they have been winless in 80% of them, and across their last 10 away fixtures they have lost 5. They have drawn 4 of their last 8 on the road, so stalemates are a recurring theme.

Current streaks fit the same narrative. Palace are undefeated in their last 5 matches in all competitions and generally trend towards resilience, with 42% of their last 12 matches in all competitions being wins by at least 2 goals, suggesting that when they get ahead they are capable of closing matches emphatically. United, by contrast, are winless in their last 3 matches across all competitions, a small but relevant wobble that puts extra pressure on their creative core.

previewParagraphs: Two of La Liga’s most watchable sides cross paths at Anoeta Stadium as Real Sociedad try to protect an impressive unbeaten run against a Villarreal team that has quietly built one of the strongest records in the division. With both coaches leaning into bold, front‑foot football, this meeting looks set to be decided by fine margins rather than sheer dominance.

Real Sociedad arrive in this match in the sort of rhythm that makes them a threat to anyone. Sergio Francisco’s side are unbeaten in their last 6 matches in all competitions, with 4 wins and 2 draws in that stretch. They are scoring 2.17 goals per game and conceding only 1 on average, numbers that underline a balanced team capable of creating chances while keeping games under control.

At Anoeta, the picture is slightly more mixed but still positive. In their last 3 home matches in all competitions, Real Sociedad have 2 wins and 1 loss, averaging 1.67 goals scored and 1.33 conceded. Interestingly, those home performances have come with lower attacking volume than away from home, with only 8 total shots and 3.67 on target per match compared to 13.83 and 6.33 overall. That suggests a more cautious approach in San Sebastián, focused on control rather than sheer shot volume.

Villarreal, under Marcelino, travel with one of the best league records so far. They sit 3rd in La Liga with 9 wins, 2 draws and just 2 defeats from 13 games. Their attack has been particularly sharp, averaging 2 goals per game, while the defence allows only 0.85, delivering a strong +15 goal difference. Across all competitions, they have won 11 of their last 20 matches and in the league they have won 15 of their last 20, remaining undefeated in 25 of their last 30 La Liga fixtures. This is a sustained run rather than a short spike.

Their away form, however, hints at vulnerability. Villarreal have won 8 of their last 15 away games in all competitions, but they have also lost 5 of their last 10 on the road. They do carry real threat, averaging 2.33 goals scored and 1 conceded in their last 6 matches overall, with 14.5 shots and 6 on target per game. Clean sheets in 3 of their last 7 away games in all competitions show they can close matches down, yet that inconsistency away from home is likely where Real Sociedad will see opportunity.

The recent history between these two at Anoeta is finely balanced. In the last 6 home meetings in all competitions, Real Sociedad have 2 wins, 1 draw and 3 losses. Villarreal have also had some emphatic days here, with Real Sociedad losing by 2 or more goals in 2 of the last 5 head to head matches. For Francisco’s team, then, this fixture carries a hint of a psychological test: they are in strong form, yet Villarreal have often found a way to hurt them.

In La Liga alone, Real Sociedad’s season has been more uneven. They sit 9th with 4 wins, 4 draws and 5 losses from 13 matches, scoring 1.31 and conceding 1.38 per game. Still, they have won 4 of their last 8 league matches and have not been defeated in 5 of their last 6 La Liga fixtures. At home in the league they have won 50% of their last 22 matches, which is solid but not dominant, reflecting why Villarreal’s stronger league record gives them a slight edge on paper.

previewParagraphs: Servette welcome Young Boys to the Stade de Genève for a Super League fixture that pits recent struggle against consistent form. With the visitors holding a notable edge in past encounters and statistical trends, the hosts have much to prove as they search for a turnaround.

Head-to-head encounters have swung in Young Boys' favour at this venue. Servette have managed only 1 win in their last 5 home meetings against Young Boys, drawing once and losing the other three. This track record illustrates the challenge ahead for the home side, who have found it tough to assert dominance in these fixtures.

Recent matchups between these two have shown Young Boys as the more clinical outfit, often capitalizing on Servette's defensive lapses. Servette last took three points against Young Boys at home more than a year ago, making the hosts eager to rewrite the narrative.

Servette enter this game looking to snap a three-match winless streak in all competitions. Over their last 6 games, they've recorded 2 wins, 1 draw, and 3 defeats, scoring an average of 1.67 goals while conceding 2 per match. While their attacking output remains steady, defensive frailty is evident.
At home, Servette have won just once in their last 3 outings, losing the other two. Goals have been scarce, with just 0.67 per game scored and 1.67 conceded on average in this stretch.

Young Boys, meanwhile, are showing contrasting momentum. Across their last 6 matches, they've gone undefeated in 5, notching 3 wins and 2 draws with only 1 loss. The attack has been potent, averaging 2.5 goals, and their defense has conceded 1.67 per game.

After 14 league matches, Servette stand 10th in the Super League table. With 4 wins, 3 draws, and 7 losses, they've netted 22 goals but shipped 27, resulting in a negative goal difference of 5. A pattern of inconsistency is apparent both at home and away.

previewParagraphs: Strasbourg welcome Brest to Stade de la Meinau seeking to build on their impressive home form, as both sides aim to shift their seasons in a positive direction. With Strasbourg holding a strong record on their own turf and Brest facing a challenging run, the stakes are clear heading into this Ligue 1 match.

Looking at Strasbourg’s recent matches, their home ground has become a fortress that few visitors breach. They are undefeated in all of their last three home games, securing two wins and a draw while conceding only once and averaging two goals per match in this stretch. Their average possession at home sits at a healthy 55%, underscoring a tendency to dictate play in front of their own goal.

Brest, on the other hand, have run into some difficulties away from home. In their last three matches on the road, they failed to register a win, with one draw and two losses. Their attacking output has been limited—just one goal scored over those matches—while conceding over two per outing on average. Possession has been an issue as well, dropping to just 35% in away fixtures.

The head-to-head history at Stade de la Meinau offers a mixed picture. Over the last five meetings in Strasbourg, the hosts have claimed just one win, with two matches ending in draws and Brest claiming two victories. This suggests that, despite Strasbourg’s current form, Brest has found ways to disrupt them in past encounters on this ground.

Across the broader campaign, Strasbourg are enjoying a productive start. Sitting in fifth with 24 goals from 13 matches, they carry a strong attacking threat (1.85 goals per game on average) and have kept goals against to just over 1.3 per match. Their home record in the Ligue 1 is particularly notable, having gone undefeated in 23 of their last 28 league matches at Stade de la Meinau and winning 60% of the last 30.

Brest’s struggles are reflected in the standings, currently lying in 14th. They have just three wins from 13 matches and have lost half of their last 12 encounters in all competitions. On the road, the difficulties compound: winless in 85% of their last 13 away games, and defeated by two or more goals in 40% of their last 20 trips. Defensive stability has been elusive, with 23 goals conceded across the season.

previewParagraphs: Two very different Premier League stories intersect at the City Ground, where Sean Dyche’s hard-edged Nottingham Forest try to stretch an unbeaten run against a Brighton side that quietly lurks around the European places. With Forest edging away from trouble and Brighton pushing toward the top six, this meeting looks less like a mismatch and more like a test of which identity holds up under pressure: Dyche’s compact structure or Fabian Hürzeler’s expansive, possession-heavy approach.

Nottingham Forest arrive in this one with a sense of growing stability. Under Sean Dyche they have become harder to break down, and the numbers over their last 6 matches in all competitions tell that story: 3 wins, 2 draws and just 1 defeat, scoring 1.67 goals and conceding only 0.83 per game. That run includes a 4 match unbeaten streak, and at the City Ground their last 3 home fixtures have brought 2 wins and a draw with 2.33 goals scored on average. It is a clear uptick for a side that has often struggled for consistency.

Brighton, meanwhile, continue to look like one of the league’s more polished outfits. They sit 6th in the Premier League with 5 wins, 4 draws and 3 losses from 12 games, backed by a positive goal difference of +3 and 1.58 goals scored per match. Across their last 6 outings in all competitions they mirror Forest’s win tally with 3 victories, 1 draw and 2 defeats, but their attacking metrics are stronger: 13.83 total shots per match and 5.17 on target, combined with an average 54.17% share of the ball. That blend of volume and control underpins their push for European qualification.

The most recent encounter between these sides offers an intriguing reference point. In March, Brighton hosted Forest and the match finished 0-0, yet the scoreline did not reflect a dull stalemate. Both teams produced 14 total shots. Forest actually managed more efforts on target, 5 to Brighton’s 2, while Brighton edged possession 53% to 47%. Dangerous attacks were finely balanced too, with Forest registering 61 to Brighton’s 58. The picture was of two sides evenly matched, Forest comfortable ceding a little of the ball but carrying a clear threat on transitions, and Brighton probing patiently without finding a way through a well-organised block.

Context around that goalless draw matters. Brighton followed familiar patterns by controlling the ball and territory, but Forest showed they can live with that style. Dyche’s side restricted clear opportunities, kept their defensive shape and still carved enough moments of danger to suggest that with sharper finishing, the outcome could easily have swung their way. That defensive resilience, now reinforced by their current unbeaten streak of 4 in all competitions, gives them a platform to challenge a top six opponent.

Over the larger league sample, however, Brighton hold the edge. Forest are 16th in the Premier League with 3 wins, 3 draws and 6 defeats from 12 matches, scoring 13 and conceding 20. They have lost 10 of their last 20 league games and have been winless in 9 of their last 11 in the competition. There is also a vulnerability to heavy defeats, with Forest losing by 2 or more goals in 42% of their last 12 Premier League outings. By contrast, Brighton have won 50% of their last 30 league fixtures and have avoided defeat in 82% of their last 17 Premier League matches, a level of consistency that underlines why they are chasing European places rather than survival.

The home trends at the City Ground are mixed. Forest have won 50% of their last 22 home league matches, but they have been winless in 8 of their last 10 at home in the Premier League and have lost half of their last 12 league games there. That suggests a side capable of strong performances on their own pitch, but also one prone to swings in form. Brighton’s broader pattern away from home is steadier; across all competitions they have been very competitive on their travels, winning by 2 or more goals in 5 of their last 13 away matches, which points to the potential for them to turn control of games into decisive scorelines.

Tactically, both managers are likely to retain their preferred 4-2-3-1 structure. Forest’s recent lineups have been remarkably consistent, with Matz Sels an ever-present in goal and a settled back four. Dyche’s team typically accept a lower share of possession, averaging 44.83% over their last 6 matches, but compensate with compact spacing and clear defensive roles. Their 11.83 shots per game and 4.17 on target in that span show they are not passive; instead, they aim for efficient use of the ball and direct progression through the lines once possession is won.

Brighton under Fabian Hürzeler lean even further into controlled build-up. Their last 6 matches in all competitions bring higher possession and more shots on goal, and their midfield pairing around Carlos Baleba has been central to that. They tend to create overloads in wide and half spaces, seeking to free their attacking midfielders between the lines. The risk for them at the City Ground is clear: push too many bodies forward and Forest have the pace and direct running to exploit transitions, especially through players like Morgan Gibbs-White pulling strings behind the striker.

previewParagraphs: As Hamburger SV and Stuttgart prepare to meet at the Volksparkstadion on November 30, 2025, both teams arrive with contrasting trajectories in the Bundesliga’s regular season. Stuttgart are keen on consolidating their top-five position, while Hamburger SV continue their search for consistency.

These two sides last met on June 5, 2023, when Stuttgart earned a 3-1 victory on HSV's home turf. Sonny Kittel opened the scoring early for Hamburg in the 6th minute, only for Stuttgart to dominate the second half. Enzo Millot struck twice, in the 48th and 64th minutes, before Silas sealed the win at the death with a goal in the 96th minute. That result extended HSV's difficult run against Stuttgart, who have now triumphed in four of their last five meetings.

Hamburger SV's struggles have been all too apparent in their last six matches, with a single victory, one draw, and four defeats. Their scoring rate has dipped to just 0.67 goals per game while conceding 1.5 on average. At home, there has been some improvement—winning and drawing one of their last three and losing the other—yet their defense remains under pressure, conceding just 0.67 at home during this span.

Stuttgart, on the other hand, approach this fixture with more confidence, winning four of their last six and drawing another, while conceding the same 1.5 goals per match as HSV but scoring a robust 2.17 per game. Their overall quality in front of goal and steady shot production (15.83 shots, 6 on target per match) highlight their attacking strength.

After 11 league games, HSV sit in 14th place with just two wins, three draws, and six defeats, scoring nine times and conceding 17. Their negative goal difference and recurring defensive issues have made turning things around tough. Stuttgart, currently fifth in the table, have racked up seven wins, one draw, and three defeats, netting 20 goals and holding a positive five-goal difference.

HSV’s recent Bundesliga run underlines their issues: they've been winless in 83% of their last 12 league matches and dropped points in seven of their last fourteen in all competitions. However, the team has also maintained an undefeated record in 80% of their last 20 home league matches, showing they can be tough to break down on their own patch.

For Stuttgart, the numbers are encouraging. They've recorded 12 wins in their last 20 and avoided defeat in 80% of their last 10 Bundesliga matches. Their road form is steadier than dominant, with five losses in their last ten away games, but they have also kept clean sheets in 40% of their last ten home league ties.

previewParagraphs: Sandefjord and KFUM Oslo square off at Komplett Arena in what could be a crucial fixture at both ends of the Eliteserien table. After suffering defeat in their previous meeting, Sandefjord have form and momentum on their side as they look to secure a top-five finish, while KFUM Oslo aim to halt a worrying winless sequence.

The story between these two teams got its latest chapter on March 30, when KFUM Oslo sealed a 3-1 home victory in their first Eliteserien encounter. Despite having less ball possession at 44% compared to Sandefjord’s 56%, KFUM Oslo’s attacking clarity made the difference, registering 14 shots and 4 on target. Sandefjord had their moments with 10 attempts, three of which tested the keeper, but were unable to match the hosts' clinical edge.

That match turned decisively in the second half. Sander Risan Mørk gave Sandefjord hope on the brink of half-time, but Johannes Núñez quickly restored parity after the break before Simen Hestnes and Moussa Njie added further goals for Oslo. The match stats reflected a close battle in midfield, but KFUM Oslo’s 55 dangerous attacks and greater efficiency in front of goal proved telling.

Since then, Sandefjord have found a more consistent groove, climbing to fifth in the standings with 14 wins from 29 matches. Their attacking output—53 goals scored at an average of 1.83 per game—outpaces Oslo's, and their goal difference of +11 speaks to a side that has balanced threat with resilience.

Recent form also tilts in Sandefjord’s favor. They have collected three wins, two draws, and only one defeat in their last six, conceding just 1.17 per game and keeping their opponents to low scoring chances. At home, they have been particularly frugal, unbeaten in their last three with two wins and a draw, and they have not conceded in that stretch. The last 3 home matches against KFUM Oslo have all ended with Sandefjord triumphant.

Sandefjord also show a habit of prolonged spells without defeat, having avoided losses in 88% of their last eight matches across all competitions. At Komplett Arena, clean sheets in six of their last twelve further emphasize their defensive organization, while eight shutouts in their last fifteen league home matches add weight to their defensive reputation.

Contrastingly, KFUM Oslo have endured tougher times, winless in their last six in all competitions and suffering three defeats along the way. Offensively, they average just a goal per match over that run, conceding at a higher rate of 1.83. Draws remain a frequent occurrence for the capital club—three in their last six overall, and half of their previous twelve matches have ended all square. Their record in away matches is equally mixed, unbeaten in 80% of their last ten but winless in 86% of their last seven outings outside Oslo, underlining a struggle to turn stalemates into victories.

Despite conceding marginally fewer goals overall so far this season (39 to Sandefjord’s 42), KFUM Oslo have managed just eight wins in 29 games, with a +3 goal difference reflective of their issues in building winning streaks. They have also gone winless in 12 of their last 15 in the league, underlining their struggles to close out matches in recent months.

Sandefjord will be without Sander Risan Mørk, Jakob Dunsby, and Martin Gjone, meaning adjustments are required for Andreas Tegström’s lineup. Drawing on first-choice selections and latest formations, Sandefjord are most likely to start in a 4-1-4-1 setup:

previewParagraphs: The closing rounds of the Eliteserien bring together two teams with contrasting ambitions, as Kristiansund BK welcome Tromsø to Kristiansund Stadion. With Tromsø eager to secure a top-two finish and Kristiansund battling towards the lower end of the standings, both sides have plenty to play for as they meet again after a dramatic September fixture.

The last contest between these two teams took place on September 24, 2025, in Tromsø. It was a match that saw the hosts take a two-goal lead through D. Braut, who netted twice in the first half (25th and 38th minutes).

Kristiansund showed resilience, pulling a goal back late in stoppage time courtesy of L. Alvheim in the 90th minute. The match ended 2-1 to Tromsø, a result that allowed them to stay in the title hunt. Kristiansund's push for an equalizer fell just short, as they failed to convert their late surge into points.

Kristiansund have shown inconsistency in their last 6 matches, picking up 2 wins, 2 draws and 2 defeats. Their attacking output stands at 1.67 goals scored per game with 2 conceded and an average of just under 40% possession.

At home, Kristiansund's form improves slightly, with 2 wins from their last 3 matches and an increased shot-on-goal average of 5 per game. Defensively, they've still averaged conceding 1.67 goals per home game over that stretch.

Tromsø have posted 3 wins and 3 losses in their previous 6 outings, but their numbers are strong: 1.5 goals scored, 1.17 conceded, and a commanding 54.33% possession. Away from home, Tromsø's last 3 outings have seen them win once and lose twice, averaging 1 goal scored and 1.33 conceded per match—but notably achieving a high volume of total shots and over 55% possession on their travels.

Kristiansund currently occupy 13th position in the table after 29 games. Their campaign registers 9 wins, 8 draws and 12 losses, with a negative goal difference of -20 as they've given up 56 goals while tallying 36 (1.24 scored, 1.93 conceded per game).

Tromsø, by contrast, sit 3rd and are chasing a lofty finish. Over 29 matches, they've secured 17 wins, drawn 3 and lost 9, scoring 47 and conceding 35 for a healthy +12 goal difference (1.62 scored, 1.21 conceded per game).

Kristiansund have found wins scarce in recent months, failing to record a victory in 16 out of their last 20 matches in all competitions. They have lost half of their last 10 matches, and 40% of their last 15 Eliteserien fixtures by a margin of at least 2 goals.

Still, there is resilience at home where they're undefeated in 8 of their last 10 league matches. Tromsø have six league wins from their last twelve fixtures (58%) and have won by 2 or more goals in 4 of their latest 10 league games. On the road, they're victorious in half of their last 18 away trips and have lost 4 of their last 8. Tromsø also hold 7 clean sheets from their most recent 15 league home games.

previewParagraphs: As the Eliteserien draws to a close, Haugesund and Bryne FK are set to lock horns in a match with much on the line. Neither side has found consistent form, but both will view this encounter as a vital opportunity to alter the course of a challenging season.

Bryne FK and Haugesund last squared off on April 21, 2025, with Bryne FK taking the spoils at home in a 3-1 victory. Although Haugesund enjoyed 59% ball possession and led the count for dangerous attacks by 63 to 36, Bryne FK were ruthless with their chances, scoring through Axel Kryger, Duarte Moreira, and Julius Eskesen before Nicklas Strunck’s late finish cushioned the margin. Haugesund managed only 3 shots on target from 10 total, compared to Bryne’s 5 from 12, underlining a difference in clinical edge despite superior possession for Haugesund.
This earlier meeting set the tone for the respective campaigns, with Bryne FK finding a way to capitalise on key moments, while Haugesund struggled to convert their dominance into meaningful results.

Neither side can claim to be entering this clash with much momentum. Haugesund have endured a rough patch, with their last 6 matches yielding 1 win and 5 defeats, scoring just 1.17 per game while conceding an average of 2.83. Home form offers little comfort: their most recent 3 games at Haugesund Stadion all ended in losses, and the average possession has tumbled under 31%.

Bryne FK’s last 6 league matches deliver a comparable story: one win, one draw, four defeats, and only 0.83 goals per match. Their away form is also a concern, with no wins and an average of 0.33 goals scored over their previous 3 away fixtures, coupled with 3.67 goals conceded per match.

Haugesund remain rooted to the foot of the Eliteserien, sitting at 16th after 29 games. The record reads just 2 wins, 3 draws, and a staggering 24 defeats, with their goal difference standing at -55. The defense has been porous, conceding 76 times at a clip of 2.62 per match, while their attack averages less than a goal per game.

Bryne FK’s campaign has been more stable yet far from comfortable. They are 14th with 7 wins, 7 draws, and 15 losses, having scored 33 and shipped 55. Their per-game averages (1.14 scored, 1.9 conceded) underline the struggles that have kept them in the lower reaches.

previewParagraphs: Bodo/Glimt are within reach of a strong finish in the Eliteserien as they host Fredrikstad at Aspmyra Stadion on November 30. With both sides aiming to close out their seasons positively, this clash brings together a high-scoring home side and a stubborn visitor with plenty of resolve.

Bodo/Glimt enter this fixture with momentum, boasting a solid track record in both recent matches and over the course of the season. With 21 wins, 4 draws, and 4 losses from 29 league matches, they hold second position, backed by a remarkable goal tally of 80—an average of 2.76 per game—while conceding less than a goal per match at 0.97.

An impressive home record stands out for Kjetil Knutsen's team. In their previous 20 home outings across competitions, they remained undefeated in 16 and collected 13 wins by at least two goals. That attacking strength is evident in their last three home matches where Bodo/Glimt averaged 3 goals scored, allowed only 0.67 against, and maintained a hefty 69.33% average possession.

Looking at their recent head-to-head history against Fredrikstad at Aspmyra Stadion, Bodo/Glimt have been hard to overcome, claiming one win and one draw in the last two encounters, conceding zero losses in the process. In fact, their overall record in the last five meetings is strong, securing four wins and two by a margin of two or more goals.

Across all competitions in their last 20 fixtures, Bodo/Glimt have been undefeated in 25 of their last 31. Their ability to secure comfortable margins is notable as they've won 9 out of their last 20 matches by at least two goals. Defensive solidity has also been a feature, earning clean sheets in 43% of the previous 30 home matches across all competitions.

Fredrikstad, meanwhile, have made their own impressions during this campaign, sitting sixth in the league with 11 wins, 9 draws, and 9 losses from 29 matches. Scoring 38 and conceding 30, their matches often hinge on defensive resilience and organized team play.

Andreas Hagen’s side have shown consistency with results in recent weeks—undefeated in 83% of their last six outings across all competitions, taking three wins along the way. Out on the road, their defensive organization is apparent with clean sheets in 40% of their last 10 away matches.

Fredrikstad do, however, have less firepower than their hosts, averaging 1.31 goals scored per match for the season. That said, they've lost only once in their last six Eliteserien games and posted two wins and a draw in their most recent three away, where they've given up just 0.5 goals per match on average.

Team selection could play a crucial role. Bodo/Glimt are missing several key squad members: Daniel Bassi, Odin Luras Bjortuft, Haitam Aleesami, Ulrik Saltnes, and Ola Brynhildsen are all sidelined. Fredrikstad will be without Johannes Núñez, Valdemar Birksø Thorsen, and Leonard Owusu.
Based on recent lineups and available personnel, the likely starting elevens are as follows:

previewParagraphs: Two teams moving in opposite directions meet at Vefa Stadı, where Fatih Karagümrük’s fight to climb away from the drop zone runs straight into a Besiktas side that has quietly pieced together one of the more solid away records in the division.

On paper this looks like a clash of different ambitions. Fatih Karagümrük sit 18th in the Süper Lig with just 2 wins from 13, while Besiktas arrive in the top half, 7th, and eyeing the European places. The contrast is not just in the table but in the underlying numbers that have shaped both campaigns so far.

Karagümrük’s league record of 2 wins, 2 draws and 9 losses, with 13 goals scored and 24 conceded, tells the story of a side that has struggled to put together complete performances. An average of 1 goal scored per game against 1.85 conceded leaves very little margin for error. Across their last 20 matches in all competitions they have lost 12 and have been winless in 80% of their last 15 games, a sequence that has gradually dragged confidence and consistency down.

Even at home, where Vefa Stadı is supposed to give them an edge, the numbers are mixed. Over their last 32 home matches in all competitions they have still managed to win 50%, and they have kept a clean sheet in 40% of their last 35 home fixtures. However, more recent trends are worrying: they have lost 50% of their last 10 home games and have been winless in 7 of their last 8 at Vefa Stadı. Losing by 2 or more goals in 43% of their last 7 home matches suggests that when they are beaten, the scoreline can quickly get away from them.

The head to head history at this ground does not offer much comfort either. In the last 3 home matches against Besiktas, Karagümrük have 0 wins, 1 draw and 2 defeats. Across the last 5 meetings with Besiktas in all venues they have lost 4 times. For a team already under pressure, that recent history underlines just how tall the task is.

Current form metrics highlight similar concerns. In their last 6 matches in all competitions, Karagümrük have 1 win, 2 draws and 3 losses, scoring only 1 goal per game on average while conceding 1.33. They have averaged 11.83 total shots and 3.17 on target, with just 43% possession. At home in their last 3 games they have been slightly more proactive, posting 11 shots and 3.67 on target with 44.67% possession, and splitting those games evenly with 1 win, 1 draw and 1 defeat. Even so, the lack of cutting edge in the final third remains a theme.

Besiktas, by contrast, look much more balanced. Seventh place with 6 wins, 3 draws and 4 defeats from 13 matches, and a goal difference of +5, reflects a side that is competitive in most fixtures. They have scored 22 league goals at a rate of 1.69 per game and conceded 17 at 1.31 per game. In all competitions they have won 19 of their last 38 matches, and their away numbers are particularly strong: 6 most recent away games have produced a 50% win rate, and they have been undefeated in 12 of their last 15 away fixtures. Winning by 2 or more goals in 38% of their last 13 away matches shows they often travel with real attacking intent.

Recent form backs that up. Over their last 6 matches in all competitions, Besiktas have 2 wins, 2 draws and 2 losses, scoring 1.67 goals per game and conceding 1.33. They average 12.67 total shots and 4 on target with 50.83% possession, figures that point to a side comfortable on the ball and capable of creating chances consistently. Their last 3 home matches have been strong too, with 2 wins and 1 draw, 2 goals scored and only 0.67 conceded on average, underlining a team that has tightened up at the back.

Team news could play a role in how both coaches approach this one. Karagümrük are without Sam Larsson, Nikoloz Ugrekhelidze, Ahmet Sivri and Berke Can Evli. That removes one of their wide creators in Larsson and thins their attacking depth on the bench. Given the last three lineups, a familiar 4-2-3-1 looks likely, with the emphasis on stability in midfield and service to a lone striker.

previewParagraphs: Two sides trapped in long winless stretches meet in Bergamo with similar problems but different approaches. Atalanta keep the ball but struggle to turn control into goals, while Fiorentina are chasing their first league win of the season despite regular flashes of danger in the final third. The numbers suggest a match decided by small details rather than sweeping dominance.

Atalanta against Fiorentina brings together two teams whose seasons have drifted into the same current: plenty of effort, a lot of control in phases, but not enough victories. Raffaele Palladino’s Atalanta sit mid table, drawing more than they win, while Paolo Vanoli’s Fiorentina arrive in serious trouble near the bottom, still searching for that elusive first Serie A success of the campaign.

The most recent chapter between these sides came in Florence on 30 March 2025, when Fiorentina edged a 1-0 home win. The match was tighter than the score suggests. Atalanta actually saw more of the ball with 55% possession and produced 39 dangerous attacks compared to Fiorentina’s 20, but crucially failed to register a single shot on target from 10 attempts. Fiorentina, with 12 shots and 4 on goal, made their efficiency count. previewParagraphs: Celta Vigo and Espanyol arrive at Balaídos with contrasting league positions but remarkably similar recent momentum, setting up a finely balanced contest between a side that draws often and one that has quietly climbed the table through narrow wins.

On paper, 13th against 6th looks straightforward, yet the underlying numbers around Celta Vigo and Espanyol tell a much more nuanced story. Celta are drawing their way through La Liga, while Espanyol have turned small margins into points, and that contrast in styles is likely to shape the pattern of this clash.

The direct meetings between these clubs have rarely been one-sided. Across the last 10 matches in all competitions between Celta Vigo and Espanyol, Celta have taken 2 wins, 5 draws and 3 losses. That means Celta have avoided defeat in 7 of those 10 games, but have only converted that into 2 victories, underlining how often this pairing has produced tight, tactical contests rather than clear-cut outcomes.

More recently, Espanyol have found ways to trouble Celta. Celta have lost 2 of their last 4 matches against Espanyol, and in their last 5 meetings they have been beaten by a margin of 2 or more goals twice. It is a small but telling shift: historically the matchup has been even, yet Espanyol’s recent trips into this fixture show a growing capacity to land decisive blows when chances appear.

Celta’s broad form in all competitions is quietly strong. Over their last 6 matches they have recorded 5 wins and 1 loss, scoring an average of 2.17 goals and conceding 1.17. They are averaging 12.67 total shots per game, with 5 on target, and holding 52.17% possession. That profile suggests a team increasingly comfortable on the ball and efficient in front of goal, with Claudio Giráldez finding a workable balance between structure and creativity.

At Balaídos, however, the picture is more mixed. In their last 3 home matches in all competitions, Celta have 1 win, 1 draw and 1 defeat, scoring 1.67 and conceding 2 per game on average. Their shot volume dips slightly to 11.33 attempts and 3.33 on target, while possession drops to 48.67%. That drop in dominance at home mirrors longer-term patterns, where Celta’s home record has been patchy despite solid overall form.

Espanyol’s recent run is similarly positive. Across their last 6 matches in all competitions, they have 4 wins and 2 losses, scoring 1.33 goals per game and conceding 1. They are generating 14.33 shots per match with 5 on target and averaging 43.83% possession. José González Álvarez has shaped a side that does not need to monopolise the ball to dictate outcomes, thriving instead on compact structure and well-timed transitions.

While their most recent numbers cited focus on home fixtures, the overall pattern is clear: Espanyol’s shot volume and defensive stability travel well, even if their away record over a longer sample has been inconsistent.

In La Liga, Celta’s league table position does not fully reflect their competitiveness. They sit 13th with 3 wins, 7 draws and 3 defeats from 13 matches, scoring 16 goals and conceding 18. That is 1.23 goals scored and 1.38 conceded per game, for a goal difference of -2. The 7 draws stand out; they point to a team that is often in matches but struggles to kill them off, which fits with their broader trend of frequently sharing the points.

Espanyol, by contrast, occupy 6th place with 6 wins, 3 draws and 4 losses from 13 matches. They have scored 17 and conceded 16, averaging 1.31 scored and 1.23 conceded per game, with a goal difference of +1. Their record paints a picture of a side slightly more clinical in tight contests, converting marginal statistical edges into victories often enough to stay in the upper third of the table.

Celta’s longer-term trends across all competitions reveal a solid foundation. They have won 7 of their last 14 matches and have not been defeated in 9 of their last 11. At home in all competitions, they have won 50% of their last 34 matches, which is respectable, but the detail is important: in the last 10 home games they have drawn 5 and have been winless in 8 of those 10. At league level this pattern is even clearer; in La Liga, Celta have drawn 50% of their last 14 matches and have not been defeated in 83% of their last 12. At Balaídos in the league, they are undefeated in 5 of their last 6 and winless in 83% of their last 12, with 6 draws in that span. It is a team very hard to beat but often unable to tilt games fully in its favour.

Espanyol’s trends combine promise with vulnerability. In all competitions they have won 50% of their last 12 matches, underlining their positive momentum. However, over their last 10 away games in all competitions they have lost 50% and have been winless in 8 of those 10, which raises questions about their ability to replicate home form on the road. In La Liga, though, they have still managed to win 50% of their last 6 matches, even as they have lost 3 in that stretch, highlighting their high-variance nature.

previewParagraphs: With both teams searching for stability in the Eredivisie standings, Ajax welcome Groningen to the Johan Cruijff Arena for a date that could shape their near-term domestic campaigns. With Ajax enduring a rough patch lately, there is a sense of urgency surrounding Fred Grim’s group, while Dick Lukkien’s Groningen look to capitalize on any lapses.

Ajax have found themselves in tough waters recently, collecting just one victory in their last six matches across all competitions, alongside one draw and four defeats. Their average goals scored per game in this period stands at 1.17, with a concerning 2.5 conceded. The home form is not much brighter. From their last three at the Johan Cruijff Arena, Ajax have claimed no wins, mustering only one point and averaging just 0.67 goals for and 2 against per match.

Groningen do not come into this clash with much better form, but there are signs of resilience. In their last six games, they've registered one win, two draws and three defeats, while scoring 1.17 and conceding 2.17 per match. Their approach has involved notably more shooting activity than Ajax, with 18 shots per match and 6.33 finding the target. However, these efforts have not always translated into points, and Groningen are also winless in four straight outings.

In their last 10 head-to-head encounters in all competitions, Ajax have a strong record, winning seven, drawing one and losing only two to Groningen. More telling is their dominance at home in this fixture, notably winning by a margin of two or more goals in all of their last nine home matches against Groningen. Their recent three meetings also edge Ajax’s way with two wins.

Ajax are currently 6th in the Eredivisie after 13 games, with five wins, five draws and three losses. They have scored 23 and conceded 19, maintaining a positive goal difference of four. The numbers show an offense averaging 1.77 per match and a defense occasionally breached but rarely overwhelmed.

Groningen sit just one place and a single point behind Ajax on the table, at 7th after 13 games. Dick Lukkien’s squad has recorded six victories, two draws and five defeats, with a matching tally of 19 goals for and 19 against. Their campaign has been characterized by streaky form and not much separating attack from defense.

Ajax’s struggle for consistency is clearly reflected in the trends. They've lost seven of their last 14 in all competitions and are winless in 83% of their last 12 fixtures. Even at home, their record shows no victories in 83% of the previous six outings. However, they have managed to keep clean sheets in 40% of their last 30 home league matches and remain undefeated in 80% of their previous 15 at home in the league.

Groningen, meanwhile, have not fared much better away from home, going winless in 16 of their last 20 matches on the road in all competitions. They have also lost three of their previous six league matches, but managed three wins from their last six away fixtures, giving them a better platform than their overall away trend would suggest.

previewParagraphs: Stadio Olimpico is set for a clash of contrasting strengths as league leaders Roma, ruthless at home and miserly in defence, face a Napoli side reshaped under Antonio Conte and built to punish the smallest lapse. With both teams in the top three and separated by fine margins in the table, this meeting has the feel of a test of how sustainable each project really is.

Roma arrive in this match carrying the authority of a side that has turned results into a habit. Top of Serie A with 9 wins and 3 losses from 12 games, they have done it with control rather than chaos, scoring 15 goals at an average of 1.25 per game while conceding only 6 at 0.5 per match. That defensive platform has underpinned a run where they have been undefeated in 82% of their last 38 league fixtures and particularly dominant at the Olimpico, winning 27 of their last 40 home games in Serie A.

The recent numbers sharpen that picture even further. Over their last 6 matches in all competitions, Roma have 5 wins and 1 loss, scoring 1.67 and conceding just 0.5 per game. Their play has been structured around possession and sustained pressure: an average of 15.33 total shots, 5.5 on target and 58.33% possession. At home across the last 3 outings those figures rise to 17 shots, 6 on target and 62% possession, evidence of a side comfortable pinning opponents back and keeping them there.

Napoli, for their part, travel with solid credentials of their own. Conte’s team sit third with 8 wins, 1 draw and 3 defeats from 12, scoring 19 goals at 1.58 per game and conceding 11 at 0.92. Stretch the lens to 40 league matches and Napoli have won 60%, remaining undefeated in 85% of their last 20 Serie A outings. Those numbers reflect a side that has learned to manage games with maturity, often controlling tempo through midfield and striking with precision when chances appear.

However, the away form tells a more nuanced story. Across their last 10 away games in all competitions, Napoli have lost 50%, and in their last 6 away matches they have been winless in 5 of those 6. Even more striking, they have lost by 2 or more goals in 43% of their last 7 away fixtures. While the overall Conte blueprint is clearly working, the team has not always transported its authority from Naples to hostile grounds.

The historical balance between the sides in Rome has been relatively even. In the last 5 league meetings at the Olimpico, Roma have taken 1 win, there have been 2 draws and Napoli have 2 victories. Broaden that to the last 10 home clashes for Roma against Napoli in all competitions and the hosts have lost 50% of those matches, suggesting that Napoli have often found ways to disrupt Roma’s rhythm in this stadium, even when the Giallorossi have been strong overall in the league.

Longer term trends give Roma reason for confidence. They have been undefeated in 21 of their last 26 home matches in all competitions and have won 26 of their last 40 home games overall, many of them with authority: 39% of their last 28 home fixtures in all competitions have been won by 2 or more goals. In Serie A alone, 38% of their last 21 home league matches have been victories by at least a 2 goal margin. Defensively, the profile is robust too, with 14 clean sheets in their last 30 home league games and average shots on target conceded kept under tight control.

Napoli’s broader data paints the picture of a high level side that occasionally leaves the door ajar. Across their last 40 matches in all competitions they have won 60% and been undefeated in 85%. Yet away from home, while there are 12 clean sheets in their last 30 away matches, the more recent pattern shows vulnerability, particularly when forced to chase games. A possession average of 52.67% away suggests they do not get overrun, but a shots on target figure of 3.47 hints at a more selective, transitional approach on the road.

previewParagraphs: A tense matchup sets the stage at Groupama Stadium as Lyon host Nantes in their Ligue 1 clash. Both sides have struggled for consistent results, but Lyon's commanding home record and Nantes' woes on the road may shape the outcome.

The Groupama Stadium is primed for Lyon versus Nantes, a fixture with intriguing recent history and significant implications for both teams. Lyon, anchored in seventh position, are looking to bounce back and reestablish themselves among the league's frontrunners. Nantes, traveling from fifteenth, face the dual challenge of lifting their season and overcoming a daunting away run.

Whenever Nantes travel to Lyon, the visiting side has found points exceedingly hard to come by. In their last five visits to the Groupama Stadium, Lyon have taken four wins and drawn once, maintaining an undefeated record on home turf against Nantes over that period. This home dominance reflects a keen ability to control direct matchups, with Lyon frequently managing to keep Nantes' attack at bay.

Lyon approach the encounter after a challenging stretch. They have managed only one win in their last six matches, alongside three draws and two defeats. Despite the low attacking returns, averaging just 1.17 goals per game in this period, their defense hasn't fared much better, conceding 1.5 per game. At home, however, Lyon have fared better, winning two of their previous three matches at Groupama, scoring an average of two and conceding just over one per game.

Nantes, meanwhile, have similarly claimed only a single victory in their past six outings, coupled with two draws and three defeats. Their attack matches Lyon’s in output at 1.17 goals per game, but their defense has proven more vulnerable, allowing two goals per match on average. Notably, recent home form for Nantes is more stable, but that statistic carries less weight as they head on the road, where winless runs have become a concerning trend.

After thirteen matches in Ligue 1’s regular season, Lyon hold a positive record of six wins, three draws, and four losses, with eighteen goals scored and fifteen conceded, yielding a goal difference of plus three. Nantes, in contrast, have won just twice, drawing five and losing six, and carry a minus seven goal difference, having conceded nineteen while notching twelve goals.

Statistical trends over a longer horizon paint a clearer picture of both teams’ momentum. Lyon have been undefeated in twelve of their last fifteen home matches in all competitions, a streak mirrored by their recent record in Ligue 1, where they have gone undefeated in sixteen of their last twenty at home. Clean sheets are also common, with four out of ten in recent home league games. On the flip side, their most recent overall record shows winless spells in six out of their last seven league matches.

Nantes’ main concern is a prolonged inability to claim wins on the road. They have been winless in sixteen of their last twenty away matches in all competitions and have lost half of their previous twelve away games. Furthermore, they have failed to win in seventeen of their last twenty-one competitive matches overall.

previewParagraphs: Porto welcome GD Estoril to the Estádio do Dragão for this Liga Portugal fixture. With the hosts currently topping the table and Estoril on a resilient unbeaten streak, the encounter promises to provide key insights into the title race and mid-table aspirations alike.

Porto have established themselves as the benchmark in Liga Portugal so far. After 11 matches, they lead the standings with 10 wins, one draw, and no losses, showcasing both consistency and defensive solidity. Their 24 goals scored against just three conceded reveal a positive goal difference of +21, and they have averaged more than two goals per game while barely allowing opponents a sniff at goal.

In contrast, GD Estoril come into the match in ninth place, with three victories, four draws, and four defeats from the same number of games. Their attacking numbers have been respectable, with 19 goals netted at an average of 1.73 per match, but they have been more vulnerable at the back, shipping 17 goals so far.

When taking recent history into account, Porto hold the edge in their last five outings against GD Estoril, winning three and losing two. While this suggests that Estoril have previously found a way past Porto, the dominant trend in their meetings leans toward the home side’s favour, with Porto collecting 11 wins from their last 15 encounters and seven of those by a margin of two or more goals.

Porto’s recent form has been sturdy, suffering just one defeat in their last six matches across all competitions. Four wins and a draw in that stretch have coincided with a narrow average win margin, scoring 1.67 and conceding only 0.83 per game. At home, they remain particularly resolute, unbeaten in their previous three fixtures and conceding just twice.

GD Estoril cannot be overlooked, however. Their last six matches saw them undefeated in five, collecting three wins and two draws. This run reflects well on the away side’s ability to probe and find results, especially given their recent average of 2.17 goals scored per match. However, they allow their opponents an average of 1.33 goals per match, highlighting some continued defensive concerns.

Delving further into long-term patterns, Porto have avoided defeat in 25 of their last 30 outings in all competitions and have registered clean sheets in nearly half of their previous 40 matches at Estádio do Dragão. Impressively, Porto have also managed to secure wins in 68% of those home matches and have claimed victory by two goals or more 50% of the time across their last 30 home league games.

Estoril’s away form in the current campaign is less formidable, with the team losing five of their last ten away games in the league. Nevertheless, their ability to remain undefeated in five consecutive matches in all competitions points to a resourceful and resilient squad, one capable of springing surprises when underestimated.

previewParagraphs: Bologna’s steady climb into the Serie A top five has not come by accident. Built on control, clean sheets and a clear identity, Andrade Davis Nicolas’ side now faces a Cremonese outfit searching for stability and goals. With one team quietly establishing European credentials and the other trying to halt a worrying slide, this meeting at the Dall’Ara looks like a test of maturity for the hosts and resilience for the visitors.

These two clubs do not share a long, intense Serie A storyline, but their latest clash in Bologna offered a useful reference point. The last time Cremonese visited the Dall’Ara in the league, the match finished in a draw, giving Bologna a home record of 0 wins, 1 draw and 0 losses from their last 1 home encounter against the Grigiorossi. That stalemate underlined how awkward Cremonese can be to break down when they stay compact, and it lingers as a reminder that Bologna, for all their progress, still have to work hard to convert dominance into victories against well-organised visitors.

Bologna enter this match in quietly imposing shape. Over their last 6 matches in all competitions, they are unbeaten with 3 wins, 3 draws and 0 losses. They have averaged 1.67 goals scored and only 0.5 conceded per game across that spell, suggesting a strong balance between attack and defence. The performance data backs that up: around 12.67 total shots per match, with 3.83 on target and an average possession of 55.67% shows a side that tends to control the ball and create a steady flow of chances rather than relying on chaotic spells.

At home, Bologna’s last 3 fixtures have been even more defensively assured. They have 1 win, 2 draws and 0 defeats, scoring 0.67 goals per game but conceding none. The goal output is modest, yet the clean sheet record highlights how difficult it has become for visiting sides to find a way through at the Dall’Ara. They still average 12.67 shots and 3 on target with the same 55.67% possession at home in that short run, pointing to a consistent pattern of control even when the scoreboard has not always fully reflected their superiority.

Cremonese’s recent path contrasts sharply. Across their last 6 matches in all competitions, they have 1 win, 2 draws and 3 losses. They are scoring 1 goal per game and conceding 1.33 on average, with 10.33 shots per match, 3.67 on target and roughly 49.17% possession. That paints a picture of a team that can create enough to be competitive but often finds itself on the wrong side of fine margins, especially defensively.

The trend becomes more concerning when we stretch the sample. Cremonese have drawn 5 of their last 10 matches in all competitions and lost 4 of their last 8. Crucially, they have been winless in 11 of their last 11 matches in all competitions, an 82% winless rate in that sequence, and they come into this game on a run of 3 straight defeats and 3 straight matches without a victory. Stopping that slide against one of the league’s more settled outfits will require a significant improvement in both penalty-box areas.

In Serie A, Bologna’s season so far looks firmly like that of a top-tier side. They sit 5th after 12 league games, with 7 wins, 3 draws and only 2 defeats. They have scored 21 goals, an average of 1.75 per match, and conceded just 8, or 0.67 per game, giving them a healthy goal difference of +13. Those numbers are not built on a short burst either. Over their last 40 league matches they have won 50%, and they are undefeated in 83% of their last 12 Serie A fixtures. At home in the league, they have won 63% of their last 40 games and are undefeated in 90% of their last 20, recording clean sheets in 50% of those 20 home encounters. This is one of the most reliable home records in the division.

Cremonese, by contrast, are sitting 11th after 12 league matches. Their Serie A record reads 3 wins, 5 draws and 4 losses, with 13 goals scored, an average of 1.08 per match, and 16 conceded, 1.33 per game, for a goal difference of -3. It is not disastrous, but it illustrates a side that struggles to outscore opponents and often ends up sharing points or narrowly losing. Their broader trend, with extended winless sequences in all competitions, suggests that turning performances into consistent results has been a persistent issue for Davide Nicola’s men.

Bologna’s long-term statistical profile is impressive. In all competitions, they have won 50% of their last 16 matches and drawn 50% of their last 6, underlining a habit of avoiding defeat. They have remained undefeated in 87% of their last 15 matches in all competitions and are currently undefeated in each of their last 11 games, a 100% undefeated run in that span. They have also recorded wins by 2 or more goals in 38% of their last 13 matches in all competitions, and that same 38% rate holds across their last 13 league games, showing that when they get on top, they often do so with a measure of comfort.

At home, the strength is even clearer. Bologna have been undefeated in 92% of their last 12 home matches in all competitions and have kept 7 clean sheets across their last 15 home outings. In Serie A at the Dall’Ara, they have won 63% of their last 40 matches and stayed undefeated in 90% of their last 20, with half of those games ending in clean sheets. These are the underlying numbers of a side that trusts its defensive structure and rarely collapses.

Cremonese’s main trend is almost the mirror image. Their last 10 matches in all competitions have brought 5 draws, underlining their tendency to be involved in tight games where neither side fully seizes control. However, with 4 defeats in their last 8 and that statistic of being winless in 11 of their last 11 matches in all competitions, confidence and momentum are clearly issues. Defensively they are not being overwhelmed, but their inability to string wins together leaves them vulnerable against teams with sharper attacking patterns.

previewParagraphs: Damak are set for a stiff challenge at Prince Sultan bin Abdulaziz Sports City Stadium as they take on an Al Ahli side carrying real momentum into this Professional League clash. With Damak yet to win a match this season, the contrast in recent form between the two teams could hardly be more stark.

Reviewing the head-to-head data, Damak have found it tough when facing Al Ahli on their own patch. In the last three home matches against Al Ahli, Damak have drawn twice and suffered one defeat. This trend underscores the home side's difficulties in earning results against their visitors.

Focusing on Damak's campaign so far, the numbers offer a sobering reality. Through nine league matches, Damak remain winless, drawing five times and losing four, with a goal difference of minus nine. They have managed fewer than one goal per match on average while conceding nearly two, placing them 16th in the table.

The recent data is consistent with these struggles. Across their last six outings, Damak have not registered a single win, settling for four draws and two defeats. They have scored an average of only 0.83 goals per game during this stretch, while allowing two per match on average.

Examining their home form, Damak continue to search for answers. The last three home games have brought two draws and one defeat, with the team averaging just 0.67 goals scored and conceding 1.33. In league terms, they have now gone winless in 10 of their last 12 home matches and 13 of their last 16 in all competitions.

Statistical trends paint a broader picture of a team in the midst of a lengthy winless run. Damak have failed to win in 25 of their last 30 Professional League fixtures and are winless in 13 consecutive matches in all competitions. Notably, draws have become a regular occurrence with half of their last 10 league and cup matches ending all square.

On the other hand, Al Ahli come in full of confidence. They have not tasted defeat in 18 of their last 20 matches across all competitions, including five wins and one draw in their last six league contests. Their record through nine matches this season places them fourth, with five wins and four draws, scoring 1.33 goals per game and only conceding 0.67 on average.

Al Ahli's defensive solidity stands out, keeping clean sheets in over half of their last 15 away matches. Their away form remains intimidating, having avoided defeat in 18 of their last 20 trips. Offensively, they have averaged 1.67 goals scored in their previous six matches while conceding just 0.5 per match.

The visitors have also shown a pattern of winning convincingly, with 13 of their last 30 matches being victories by at least two goals. Al Ahli’s consistent results are mirrored by their strong performances on the road, winning 63% of their last 40 away fixtures across all competitions.

Given these figures, Al Ahli appear well placed to capitalize against a Damak side lacking in attacking threat. The algorithm prediction suggests a likely outcome of over 2.5 goals, with the most probable scoreline set at 2-1 in Al Ahli's favor and a 56% probability for their victory.

Looking at probable formations and team news, both teams have regularly lined up in a 4-2-3-1 or 4-1-4-1. For Damak, the frequent starters feature between the sticks and through the back four, while Al Ahli’s reliable structure and unchanged backline provide a solid foundation.
